EXAMPLE: BLUE OCEAN STRATEGY
W. Chan Kim and Renee Mauborgne
“Blue Ocean Strategy” 
(Harvard Business Review: Oct, 2004)
Red Oceans and Blue Oceans
… the business universe consists of two distinct kinds of space, which we think of as red and blue oceans. Red oceans represent all the industries in existence today-the known market space. In red oceans, industry boundaries are defined and accepted, and the competitive rules of the game are well understood. Here, companies try to outperform their rivals in order to grab a greater share of existing demand. As the space gets more and more crowded, prospects for profits and growth are reduced. Products turn into commodities, and increasing competition turns the water bloody.
Blue oceans denote all the industries not  in existence today – the unknown market space, untainted by competition. In blue oceans, demand is created rather than  fought over. There is ample opportunity for growth that is both profitable and rapid. There are two ways to create blue oceans:
In a few cases, companies can give rise to completely new industries, as eBay did with the online auction industry. 
But in most cases, a blue ocean is created from within a red ocean when a company alters the boundaries of an existing industry.
title: Pws Notes (Part 101)

content:
Four Actions Framework
To achieve value innovation, Kim and Mauborgne propose an analytical tool they call the Four Actions Framework. These four key questions challenge an industry’s strategic logic and established business model: 
Which of the factors that the industry takes for granted should be eliminated
 
Which factors should be reduced well below the industry standard
 
Which factors should be raised well above the industry standard
 
Which factors should be created that the industry has never offered

In addition to value innovation, Kim and Mauborgne propose exploring non-customer groups to create Blue Oceans and tap untouched markets.

CASE STUDY: WINE
title: Pws Notes (Part 102)

content:
Wine is Old
Wine has been around for thousands of years in the countries surrounding the Mediterranean, but France has made it a part of their civilization and has considered wine-making as an art for over two thousand years. 
Not only did the Gauls know how to cultivate the vine, they also knew how to prune it, making the  difference between wild vines and wine producing grapes. Before long, the wines produced in Gaul were exceptionally famous all around the world.
French wines have set the standard for the wine industry for centuries.
Main Types of Wine 
Five Main Types of Wine
All wines can be organized into five basic groups. Within each group there are hundreds of different grape varieties and winemaking techniques! 
Red Wine: Still wine made with black grapes. Red wines range from light to bold.
White Wine: A still wine produced from white and occasionally black grapes. Flavors in white wines span from light to rich.
Rosé Wine: Still wine from black grapes produced by removing the skins before they stain the wine deep red. Rosé is also made by blending red and white wine together. Both dry and sweet styles of rosé are common.
Sparkling Wine: A style of winemaking involving a secondary fermentation that makes bubbles! Sparkling wine can be red, white, or rosé and ranges from lean and dry, to rich and sweet.
Dessert Wine: A style of winemaking involving fortifying wine with spirits. Typically, dessert wines taste sweet, but many dry, fortified wines exist, such as dry Sherry.
The Traditional Producers
Chateau Pichon-Longueville in Pauillac, Bordeaux  (France)
The Traditional Vocabulary

Finding the Holes
Scientific puzzle solving is like jigsaw-puzzle solving in another way as well. When enough pieces have been fitted together, they may define either a whole or a hole. Both are valuable. 
The whole is a new structure that makes sense of the available data. 
But the hole—what is not there—is also useful because it is a valuable clue to the shape of our ignorance. 
Having defined that shape, we can now look for specific pieces to fill the hole. Our search for linkages is no longer random. We have a specific question to answer and definite criteria to use in evaluating possible answers. 
Almost every scientist of note has said something along the lines of “properly defining your question gets you more than halfway to its solution.” Questions, from this point of view, are also patterns.

Roberto Verganti
Overcrowded: Designing Meaningful Products in a World Awash with Ideas
(Massachusetts Institute of Technology: 2016)
The Innovation of Meaning
How to create innovations that people love
 Research in different domains has shown that we don’t buy products, ideas, technologies, or features alone. We buy meanings. 
The more meaningful something is, the more we are attracted to it. Innovation has typically been seen as a matter of “problem solving”. Firms compete to provide better solutions to problems. From this perspective meanings are considered something to understand, not something to innovate. But meanings cannot merely be understood. Meanings can also change and be innovated.
…innovation driven by design is and how it stands apart from other approaches of innovation. It shows that design is related to the innovation of the meaning of products and services: an innovation that concerns the purpose, the ‘why’ people use things, rather than the functionality and performance of products (i.e. the ‘what’ and ‘how’).
Example:  “Consumption-driven wealth and status are being replaced by identity, belonging, and a strong desire to contribute and do something “meaningful” rather than just acquire things.”
title: Pws Notes (Part 114)

content:
Example
Example
Look Beyond Features and Functions
…people do not buy products but meanings. People use things for profound emotional, psychological, and sociocultural reasons as well as utilitarian ones. Analysts have shown that every product and service in consumer as well as industrial markets has a meaning. Firms should therefore look beyond features, functions, and performance and understand the real meanings users give to things. The common assumption, however, is that meanings are not a subject for innovation: they are a given. One must understand them but cannot innovate them. 
Innovation has therefore focused on two strategies: quantum leaps in product performance enabled by breakthrough technologies, and improved product solutions enabled by better analysis of users’ needs. The former is the domain of radical innovation pushed by technology, and the latter of incremental innovation pulled by the market. 
People Do Not Buy Products, They Buy Meaning
However, companies such as Nintendo, Apple, Artemide, Whole Foods Market, Alessi, and many others discussed in this book show that meanings do change—and that they can change radically. These firms therefore also purse a third strategy: design-driven innovation— that is, radical innovation of meaning. Think for example at the Nintendo Wii that transformed consoles from a passive immersion in a virtual world approachable only by niche experts into an active physical entertainment for everyone, in the real world, through socialization. Or at Whole Foods Market, that has radically changed the meaning of healthy nutrition from a severe, self-denying choice to a hedonic one, and shopping from a chore to a reinvigorating experience.
These firms have not provided people with an improved interpretation of what they already mean by, and expect from, a console or an organic food store. Rather, they have proposed a different and unsolicited meaning, that was what people were actually waiting for. 
THE DESIGN-DRIVEN INNOVATIONS INTRODUCED BY THESE FIRMS HAVE NOT COME FROM THE MARKET BUT HAVE CREATED HUGE MARKETS. They have generated products, services, and systems with long lives, significant and sustainable profit margins, and brand value, and they have spurred company growth.
New Meaning as the Driver of Value
Creating innovations of meaning brings your interaction with customers to a higher level: the level of love. It focuses on what worth really is: value for a person. People do not fall in love with a better  performance. That's a date. Love for a person, as well as for anything in life, comes from meaning. The best metaphor for describing innovation of meaning is to think of it as a "gift.”
In our current world, however, the main driver of value is not just meaning, but new meaning. Customers nowadays face an unprecedented scenario: their context changes at an extreme speed, and therefore their problems and search for meaning keep changing. Companies that focus on innovating solutions often find themselves launching a great new product that unfortunately solves a problem that meanwhile has become old. There is no value in a better performance if this performance is no longer meaningful.

WICKED PROBLEMS

Wicked Problems
A wicked problem is a social or cultural problem that is difficult or impossible to solve for as many as four reasons: 
incomplete or contradictory knowledge, 
the number of people and opinions involved, 
the large economic burden, and 
the interconnected nature of these problems with other problems. 
Example: poverty is linked with education, nutrition with poverty, the economy with nutrition, and so on.

These problems are typically offloaded to policy makers, or are written off as being too cumbersome to handle en masse. 
Yet these are the problems—poverty, sustainability, equality, and health and wellness—that plague our cities and our world and that touch each and every one of us.
title: Pws Notes (Part 118)

content:
Characteristics of Wicked Problems
Horst Rittel, one of the first to formalize a theory of wicked problems, cites ten characteristics of these complicated social issues:
Wicked problems have no definitive formulation. The problem of poverty in Texas is grossly similar but discretely different from poverty in Nairobi, so no practical characteristics describe “poverty.” 
It’s hard, maybe impossible, to measure or claim success with wicked problems because they bleed into one another, unlike the boundaries of traditional design problems that can be articulated or defined. 
Solutions to wicked problems can be only good or bad, not true or false. There is no idealized end state to arrive at, and so approaches to wicked problems should be tractable ways to improve a situation rather than solve it. 
There is no template to follow when tackling a wicked problem, although history may provide a guide. Teams that approach wicked problems must literally make things up as they go along. 
There is always more than one explanation for a wicked problem, with the appropriateness of the explanation depending greatly on the individual perspective of the designer. 
Every wicked problem is a symptom of another problem. The interconnected quality of socio-economic political systems illustrates how, for example, a change in education will cause new behavior in nutrition. 
No mitigation strategy for a wicked problem has a definitive scientific test because humans invented wicked problems and science exists to understand natural phenomena. 
Offering a “solution” to a wicked problem frequently is a “one shot” design effort because a significant intervention changes the design space enough to minimize the ability for trial and error.
Every wicked problem is unique. 
Designers attempting to address a wicked problem must be fully responsible for their actions.
title: Pws Notes (Part 119)

content:
﻿A system is an interconnected set of elements that is coherently organized in a way that achieves something. 
If you look at that definition closely for a minute, you can see that a system must consist of three kinds of things: 
elements, 
interconnections, and 
a function or purpose.
﻿Systems can be embedded in systems, which are embedded in yet other systems. 
Is there anything that is not a system
 Yes—a conglomeration without any particular interconnections or function. Sand scattered on a road by happenstance is not, itself, a system.
﻿A system is more than the sum of its parts. It may exhibit adaptive, dynamic, goal-seeking, self-preserving, and sometimes evolutionary behavior.
Implications
A system is the product of the interactions of its subsystems, and not the sum of its parts.
To improve the system, do not focus on improving the performance of its parts, but how well the parts interact. 
Sometimes it is necessary to worsen the performance of a part of the system in order to improve the functioning of the whole (e.g., an engine that is too powerful for a car’s transmission or brakes). Other times the interrelationship needs to be changed or improved.
There is, therefore, no such thing as a ‘marketing’… ‘sales’… ‘production’… ‘personnel’… ‘financial’… problem. 
The solution is, in the majority of cases, in areas different from where they appear (e.g., a sales problem may be due to a production coordination problem), and lies instead in the interactions of these subsystems.

Stocks and Flows
Stock and Flow Diagrams
Causal Loop Diagrams and Stocks and Flows
For example, consider the simple reinforcing loop of Births and Population. Because Births is a flow (representing the rate of increase in Population), and Population is a stock, a CLD (causal loop diagram) does not represent this system as accurately as does a stock and flow diagram. In the CLD, both links in this loop are “s” links, indicating that as Births increase, Population increases (a change in the same direction), and as Population increases, Births increase (another change in the same direction).
However, this representation is not completely accurate. If Birth Rate declines, causing Births to decrease, say from 1000 to 900 per month, Population does not in turn decrease; it continues to increase, only at a slower rate than before. Thus the “s” link from Births to Population is accurate only when Births is increasing, because Births and Population do not move in the same direction when Births decrease.
In contrast, a stock and flow diagram makes it visually apparent that Births is an inflow to Population and thus can only increase it, not decrease it (because there cannot be a negative number of births). This distinction between stocks and flows makes stock and flow diagrams a more accurate rendition of the system being represented.

content:
Summary
R1 (Fish Regenera8on Loop): More adult fish leads to more regeneration rate for a given fractional regeneration rate, which generates more adult fish a9er the maturation time delay. This is the key regeneration loop that causes fish population to grow over time . 
B2 (Limits to Growth Loop): Healthy ecosystem in the diagram denotes carrying capacity. There is a carrying capacity in the marine ecosystem that supports a given amount of fish population. More fish, higher fish density for a given carrying capacity (thus less nutrients per fish), which leads to lower fractional regeneration rate. When total fish population reaches its carrying capacity, reproduction slows down, as there is no more capacity to support further population growth. Starting from a small population relative to this carrying capacity, the fish population over time will grow and eventually stabilizes near this carrying capacity. 
R2 (Race for Fish Loop): less adult fish stock, less catch per unit effort, which lowers fishing income and drives up fishing effort. More fishing effort increases catch and further declines fish stock. This is a key reinforcing loop that causes the fishery to collapse. 
R3 (Fish Price Loop): overfishing (both legal and illegal catch) causes market price to collapse and reduces income, which drives up fishing effort and leads to further overfishing. 
R4 (Erosion of Carrying Capacity Loop): more fishing effort leads to more habitat damage and erodes carrying capacity, which lowers regeneration rate and increases mortality rate that leads to fishery decline. 
R5 (Economic Growth Loop): less fishing income leads to more non‐fishing activities such as aquaculture and agriculture. Without proper regulation, these economic activities increase pollution and cause faster erosion of healthy ecosystem. 
R6 (Healthy Ecosystem Loop): habit conservation and pollution regulation improve ecosystem health, which attract eco‐tourism as alternative income, reduce fishing effort and polluting activities, and further improve ecosystem health. 
R7 (Sustainable Fish Loop): healthy ecosystem improves fish quality. Under Catch Shares program, fishermen have incentives to improve the health of fishery, which could lead to higher price premium for certified fish. Higher price allows fishermen to meet their income target with lower catch, which helps restore the fish stock. 
R8 (Civic Engagement Loop): sense of urgency, program benefits and stakeholder trust building increase civic engagement in program implementation, which further reinforce program benefits, trust building and civic engagement. This is a key implementation loop for scaling up the fishery restoration.

“Solving” a Systems Problem: Leverage Points
Addressing the root causes of problems requires that participants identify “leverage points” that impact the whole system, and address those leverage points in a strategic, coordinated effort that sustains over time.
Leverage points are places in a system where, as systems theorist Donella Meadows has said, “a small shift in one thing can produce big changes in everything.” 
Leverage points are like acupuncture points — places where a finely tuned, strategic intervention is capable of creating lasting change, creating positive ripple effects that spread far and wide.
How to Use Leverage Points
Change the flow rates – what can we slow down and what can we speed up in order to positively impact the system

Add a feedback loop – Feedback loops employ information to prompt action. For example, when the thermostat reaches a certain temperature, it turns on the AC system to provide cooler air. Rather than being stuck in the inertia of doing what we always do, new information gives us the opportunity to behave differently.
New subsystems – are there new subsystems that can be added to positively impact the system

Challenge assumptions – Everything in a system — its elements, interconnections, feedback loops — bends towards the achievement of its goal. This insight leads to our final two tools. First, many systems get stuck with certain assumptions about how the goal is supposed to be achieved. 
Change the rules – can the rules that govern a subsystem (or the system as a whole) be changed in order to positively impact the system
 Rules are formalized interconnections. They dictate how different elements are supposed to interact within a system. Changing rules can produce drastic changes in behavior. 
Change the goal – If the most important part of a system is its goal, then our most powerful tool is changing that goal. Changing a goal often starts with simply questioning the behavior or outcomes that a system produces.

APPENDIX:
SYSTEMS THINKING
Ackoff’s Pyramid
Basics of Systems Thinking
We build knowledge from information we are taking in from our senses
Mental models are how we structure knowledge, and determine how we perceive, feel, and act
Thinking is how we build meaning from knowledge
Four patterns determine how we build mental models:
We make distinctions (using all of our senses) between things and things (e.g., drink and food) because everything has an identity (i.e., we see what a thing is and what it is is not which makes it unique and not something else)
We organize things into systems of parts and wholes (whether simple or complex)
We identify relationships (i.e., interactions) among the parts and wholes, whether reaction and re-action or cause and effect (whether between and among people, objects, or ideas)
We take perspectives from a point or a view on the world around us (parts and wholes; and relationships) as we navigate the world ad think about it; and what we think is determined by our mental models (e.g., compassion, empathy, distance)
title: Pws Notes (Part 130)

content:
And mental models determine how we make distinctions, organize parts into wholes, identify relationships, and take perspectives
Sometimes we care about the parts, and sometimes we care about the whole; but we can never ignore how they relate to each other; i.e., behavior
APPENDIX:
SYSTEMS THINKING
Russ Ackoff
Analysis
The Dominance of Analysis  
Analysis is the dominant form of thinking today. To take the whole apart to understand its parts, how they work, fit together, etc. It requires a reduction to indivisible parts, e.g., atoms in physics, elements in chemistry, cellular components in biology, etc. (Subject to level of analysis issues)

Cause and Effect 
In the analytical framework, the relation of things is itself reducible: to cause and effect. 
Major assumptions: Causes and effects must exclude the environment (e.g., bodies falling in a vacuum), and there is limited role for chance or randomness. Pierre Simon Laplace: “We may regard the present state of the universe as the effect of its past and the cause of its future.”  
Causes can be followed back to the first cause (i.e., God).  
Isaac Newton: The universe is a machine, created by God.
General Systems Theory
Ludwig Bertalanffy’s General Systems Theory changed thinking to look at systems.
title: Pws Notes (Part 131)

content:
A system is a whole that consists of two or more parts, such that: 
each part can affect the behavior of the whole; 
each part cannot independently affect the whole -- but interacts with or affects the others;
the subsets of the parts have similar systemic properties.

When a system is taken apart it loses its essential properties.  Therefore: you cannot understand a system through analysis.

It is not the sum of its parts but the product of its interactions. Its interactions need to be understood.

Synthesis
See the system in question as part of a larger system, i.e., what is the system a component of
 (e.g. the University is part of the larger educational system)

Consider the larger system or systems it is part of (e.g. the educational system, the society, etc.)

Understand the role or function of the subsystem within the larger system (e.g. what is the role of the University in the educational system
)

Describe the parts that are essential to the system in question and how they interact: It is the relations of the subsystems that are the keys to improvement, not the functioning of the subsystems themselves.
title: Pws Notes (Part 132)

content:
Synthesis, continued…
Some implications: 
A system is the product of the interactions of its subsystems, and not the sum of its parts.
To improve the system, do not focus on improving the performance of its parts, but how well the parts interact. Sometimes it is necessary to worsen the performance of a part of the system in order to improve the functioning of the whole (e.g., an engine that is too powerful for a car’s transmission or brakes). Other times the interrelationship needs to be changed or improved.
There is, therefore, no such thing as a ‘marketing’… ‘sales’… ‘production’… ‘personnel’… ‘financial’… problem. The solution is, in the majority of cases, in areas different from where they appear (e.g., a sales problem may be due to a production coordination problem), and lies instead in the interactions of these subsystems.
Analysis vs. Synthesis
Analysis reveals how it works (what does each part do
) 
Synthesis reveals why it works the way it does (why it does what it does in its environment).
Determinism vs. Teleology

Systems thinking is the fusion of analysis and synthesis.

From Mechanistic to Systemic Thinking 
Machines are created to serve a function for their creator. 
Organisms are created with purposes of their own.

Some Observations: 
Machine Age thinking often involves the pursuit of the wrong ends: We care about efficiency (how to do something economically) as opposed to effectiveness (what to do and why).   We do the wrong thing rightly as opposed to the right thing wrongly.

Examples: 
The health care system: More realistically the “sick and disabled system,” as the incentive (and provider pay) is to treat the sick and disabled. The focus is on the efficient maintenance of sick people. The incentives, ironically, lead to more sick and disabled people, not healthier ones.

The education system:  The objective of college should not be to teach more efficiently. It should be to get students to learn how to learn (perhaps by teaching the teachers) and to be motivated to do it.

content:
DONELLA H. MEADOWS
﻿Edited by Diana Wright
(Sustainability Institute CHELSEA GREEN PUBLISHING: 2008)
Introduction
﻿A system is an interconnected set of elements that is coherently organized in a way that achieves something. 
If you look at that definition closely for a minute, you can see that a system must consist of three kinds of things: 
elements, 
interconnections, and 
a function or purpose.
﻿Systems can be embedded in systems, which are embedded in yet other systems. 
Is there anything that is not a system
 Yes—a conglomeration without any particular interconnections or function. Sand scattered on a road by happenstance is not, itself, a system.
﻿A system is more than the sum of its parts. It may exhibit adaptive, dynamic, goal-seeking, self-preserving, and sometimes evolutionary behavior.
How Do You Know

﻿How to know whether you are looking at a system or just a bunch of stuff: 
Can you identify parts
 . . . and 
Do the parts affect each other
 . . . and 
Do the parts together produce an effect that is different from the effect of each part on its own
 . . . and perhaps 
Does the effect, the behavior over time, persist in a variety of circumstances
title: Pws Notes (Part 135)

content:
The Flow of Information
﻿Many of the interconnections in systems operate through the flow of information. Information holds systems together and plays a great role in determining how they operate.
﻿If information-based relationships are hard to see, functions or purposes are even harder. A system’s function or purpose is not necessarily spoken, written, or expressed explicitly, except through the operation of the system. The best way to deduce the system’s purpose is to watch for a while to see how the system behaves.
﻿Purposes are deduced from behavior, not from rhetoric or stated goals.
﻿An important function of almost every system is to ensure its own perpetuation.
﻿Keeping sub-purposes and overall system purposes in harmony is an essential function of successful systems.
﻿A change in purpose changes a system profoundly, even if every element and interconnection remains the same.
Stocks and Flows
﻿A stock is the foundation of any system. Stocks are the elements of the system that you can see, feel, count, or measure at any given time. A system stock is just what it sounds like: a store, a quantity, an accumulation of material or information that has built up over time. It may be the water in a bathtub, a population, the books in a bookstore, the wood in a tree, the money in a bank, your own self-confidence. A stock does not have to be physical.
﻿ ﻿A stock is the memory of the history of changing flows within the system.
Stocks change over time through the actions of a flow. Flows are filling and draining, births and deaths, purchases and sales, growth and decay, deposits and withdrawals, successes and failures. A stock, then, is the present memory of the history of changing flows within the system.
Examples
Feedback Loops
﻿﻿Systems thinkers see the world as a collection of stocks along with the mechanisms for regulating the levels in the stocks by manipulating flows. That means system thinkers see the world as a collection of “feedback processes.”
title: Pws Notes (Part 136)

content:
A feedback loop is formed when changes in a stock affect the flows into or out of that same stock.

﻿Feedback loops can cause stocks to maintain their level within a range or grow or decline. In any case, the flows into or out of the stock are adjusted because of changes in the size of the stock itself. Whoever or whatever is monitoring the stock’s level begins a corrective process, adjusting rates of inflow or outflow (or both) and so changing the stock’s level. The stock level feeds back through a chain of signals and actions to control itself.
title: Pws Notes (Part 137)

content:
﻿A feedback loop is a closed chain of causal connections from a stock, through a set of decisions or rules or physical laws or actions that are dependent on the level of the stock, and back again through a flow to change the stock.
Balancing and Reinforcing Feedbacks
﻿Balancing feedback loops are equilibrating or goal-seeking structures in systems and are both sources of stability and sources of resistance to change.
﻿The presence of a feedback mechanism doesn’t necessarily mean that the mechanism works well. The feedback mechanism may not be strong enough to bring the stock to the desired level. Feedbacks—the interconnections, the information part of the system—can fail for many reasons. Information can arrive too late or at the wrong place. It can be unclear or incomplete or hard to interpret. The action it triggers may be too weak or delayed or resource-constrained or simply ineffective.
﻿The second kind of feedback loop is amplifying, reinforcing, self-multiplying, snowballing—a vicious or virtuous circle that can cause healthy growth or runaway destruction. It is called a reinforcing feedback loop, and will be noted with an R in the diagrams. It generates more input to a stock the more that is already there (and less input the less that is already there). A reinforcing feedback loop enhances whatever direction of change is imposed on it.
﻿Reinforcing feedback loops are self-enhancing, leading to exponential growth or to runaway collapses over time. They are found whenever a stock has the capacity to reinforce or reproduce itself.
LEARN TO THINK IN SYSTEMS
ALBERT RUTHERFORD
(KINDLE DIRECT PUBLISHING: 2019)
Parts of a System
﻿Systems are made up of three parts:
Elements; 
Interconnections;
Functions or purpose. 
The word “function” is used when talking about a non-human system, and the word “purpose” is used for human systems. 
Elements are the actors in the system. 
The interconnections show the relationship of these actors with one another. 
The function or purpose is the voluntary or involuntary motivator and catalyst for the elements’ interconnections.
Stocks and Flows
﻿Donella Meadows, in her book Thinking in Systems: A Primer, refers to stocks and flows as being the foundation of every system.
Stock:  A stock can be something physical, like the amount of money in your account, your business inventory, or the information needed to write a book. However, stocks don’t necessarily have to be physical things. They can also be feelings or attitudes people hold. The amount of anger you hold toward a cheating spouse or an alcoholic parent can also be viewed as a stock. Stocks are not static. They change over time based on the impacts of a flow. Stocks are snapshots in time, showing a current condition of the changing flows in the system. 
Flow:  Flows are the actions that impact a system. A flow might be a success or a failure, purchases or sales, deposits or withdrawals, births or deaths, or growths or declines. To illustrate how flows impact the stocks, I’ve added Picture 3. The rectangle stands for the stock. This stock is affected by two flows, specifically an inflow and an outflow. Stocks can be affected by multiple inflows and outflows, but for the sake of simplicity let’s stick to only one of each. The little clouds represent where the flows come from or go. Flows can be increased or decreased through intervention.
The General Rules of Stocks and Flows
﻿If there are more inflows than outflows, the level of stock will increase. 
If there are more outflows than inflows, the level of stock will decrease. 
If the amount of outflows and inflows is equal, the stock level will remain at its current level and will be unchanged. This is called dynamic equilibrium. 
The level of a stock is increased if its outflow is decreased or its inflow is increased. 
Stocks provide a security barrier in a system, since they serve to delay the initial shock that may affect a system. 
Stocks preserve the ability of inflows and outflows to remain independent.
COMPONENTS
﻿Systems dynamics show the nonlinear behavior tendencies of complex systems. 
With the help of stocks, flows, feedbacks, and delays we can detect how quickly changes happen within the system. Often the behavior of the whole system can’t be explained based only on the behavior of its individual parts. In other words, determining what kinds of interactions are at play between the elements is very important. 
Stocks and flows are the building blocks of the systems dynamics model. 
The components of systems stories are: 
Variables; 
Links; 
Mental Models; 
Direction of Links; 
Delays; 
Feedback Loops
Variables
﻿Variables are usually neutral nouns. They present elements in situations where behavior patterns change over time. 
David Peter Stroh, a systems thinking expert, defines variables as “the nouns of Systems Thinking language. They are the key forces in a systems story that impact each other and change, or literally vary, over time. As such they are critical elements in building a compelling understanding of what has been happening and why. Systems Thinking has the advantage of being able to combine quantitative variables such as profits with qualitative variables such as morale.”
Variables in systems thinking language have a few strict characteristics. Besides being neutral nouns, they are not events. The value of a variable can go up and down over time. The nouns you use for variables should incorporate the level of change over time.
﻿Performance measuring variables: When we want to solve a complex problem with the help of systems thinking, we usually face an issue with more than one “symptom of dysfunction.” It’s a good idea to also have more than one performance measure we wish to understand and change.
﻿Stroh identifies and groups five types of general variables: “
Goals 
Desired level of __________ 
Thinking/feeling/perceptions  
Level of commitment to __________ 
Level of alignment around __________ 
Level of clarity about __________ 
Perceived level of __________ 
Morale 
Demand  
Pressure to __________ 
Need for __________ 
Demand to __________ 
Gap between __________ and __________ 
Competitive Pressure 
Supply  
Capacity for __________ 
Ability to __________ 
Available resources (e.g., time/people/experience) for __________ 
Investment in __________ 
Results  
Actual level of performance (e.g., profitability, revenue, cycle time, cost, turnover, customer satisfaction, market share) 
Quality of __________”
Links and the Direction of Links
﻿To discover and understand links, one should select a variable and ask: 
What are possible causes for an increase or decrease in this variable
 Name these factors as variables (nouns, something that can increase or decrease). 
What are the possible consequences or effects of an increase or decrease in this variable
 Name these effects as variables.
﻿We can assess which direction the first variable will pull the second. In systems thinking language, we differentiate two directions: the same direction (S) or the opposite direction (O).
﻿When you design a feedback or causal diagram, it’s good to indicate the direction of your links. This practice not only makes the diagram easier to follow but also helps to discover possible missing variables that could add important information to the analysis.
Mental Models
﻿Mental models are our (or the system’s) beliefs, norms, and cultural "truths." 
These are important determinants of the system’s behavior we are examining.
﻿Interventions that disregard the importance of habits and beliefs end up being costly and ineffective. 
Changes in any infrastructure without the close following of belief changes are not successful.
Feedback Loops
﻿When a system displays a consistent behavior over time, it is likely there is a mechanism at work controlling and creating that behavior. The mechanism works through what we call a feedback loop. Feedback loops either keep a stock’s level within a certain range or make it increase or decrease. No matter the feedback loop’s strength, the inflows and outflows to and from the stock are determined by the size of the stock itself.
﻿Again, the stock’s size determines the amount of increase or decrease the feedback loop generates over time. Identifying the variables and the links between them leads to the discovery of a feedback loop (or causal loop – both names are used interchangeably).
﻿There are two types of feedback loops. …The performance-over-time pattern gives a visible hint about the structure determining the behavior. 
Reinforcing processes lead to growth or decay. They are often referred to as vicious or virtuous cycles. 
Balancing processes work to stabilize the stock at a given level. The balancing process can be referred to as a goal-seeking or limiting due to a constraint.
﻿The loops can be designed to be read either clockwise or counterclockwise. All that matters is consistency and the correct order of the relationship. 
A loop can’t be reinforcing and balancing at the same time. If you can’t decide which case applies, it means the story is not yet finished. Add more variables and links to the loop story until you can determine the nature of the loop (balancing or reinforcing).

Example: How to Prevent Skidding: Anti-Lock Brakes
Stopping a car in a hurry on a slippery road can be very challenging. Anti-lock braking systems (ABS) take a lot of the challenge out of this sometimes nerve-wracking event. In fact, on slippery surfaces, even professional drivers can't stop as quickly without ABS as an average driver can with ABS.
The theory behind anti-lock brakes is simple. A skidding wheel(where the tire contact patch is sliding relative to the road) has less traction than a non-skidding wheel. If you have been stuck on ice, you know that if your wheels are spinning you have no traction. This is because the contact patch is sliding relative to the ice. By keeping the wheels from skidding while you slow down, anti-lock brakes benefit you in two ways: You'll stop faster, and you'll be able to steer while you stop.

content:
Mind Mapping
A mind map is a diagram used to represent words, ideas, tasks, or other items linked to and arranged radially around a central key word or idea. Mind maps are used to generate, visualize, structure, and classify ideas, and as an aid in study, organization, problem solving, decision making, and writing.
The elements of a given mind map are arranged intuitively according to the importance of the concepts, and are classified into groupings, branches, or areas, with the goal of representing semantic or other connections between portions of information. Mind maps may also aid recall of existing memories.
By presenting ideas in a radial, graphical, non-linear manner, mind maps encourage a brainstorming approach to planning and organizational tasks. Though the branches of a mind map represent hierarchical tree structures, their radial arrangement disrupts the prioritizing of concepts typically associated with hierarchies presented with more linear visual cues. This orientation towards brainstorming encourages users to enumerate and connect concepts without a tendency to begin within a particular conceptual framework.
The Rules of Mind Mapping
The rules of mind mapping are “intended to help you to a free and good judgment.” They are “the children of sound experience,” having been extensively tested and refined over the past thirty years. 
All you need to begin mind mapping is a topic, a few colored pens, and a large sheet of paper. Follow these rules: 
Begin your mind map with a symbol or a picture (representing your topic) at the center of your page. Starting at the center opens your mind to a full 360 degrees of association. Pictures and symbols are much easier to remember than words and enhance your ability to think creatively about your subject. 
Write down key words. Key words are the information-rich “nuggets” of recall and creative association. 
Connect the key words with lines radiating from your central image. By linking words with lines (“branches”), you’ll show clearly how one key word relates to another. 
Print your key words. Printing is easier to read and remember than writing. 
Print one key word per line. By doing this, you free yourself to discover the maximum number of creative associations for each key word. The discipline of one word per line also trains you to focus on the most appropriate key word, enhancing the precision of your thought and minimizing clutter. 
Print your key words on the lines and make the length of the word the same as the line it is on. This maximizes clarity of association and encourages economy of space. 
Use colors, pictures, dimension, and codes for greater association and emphasis. Highlight important points and illustrate relationships between different branches of your mind map. You might, for instance, prioritize your main points through color coding, highlighting in yellow the most important points, using blue for secondary points, and so forth. Pictures and images, preferably in vivid color, should be used wherever possible; they stimulate your creative association and greatly enhance your memory.
title: Pws Notes (Part 145)

content:
Step 1
Let’s say that the topic for this mind map is the Renaissance. 
Start your mind map by drawing a representative image in the middle of the paper. 
Draw it as vividly as you can, using more than one color. 
Have fun and don’t worry about the accuracy of your drawing.

Step 2
Now print key words or draw images on lines radiating out from your central image.
Remember print on the lines, one key word or image per line, and keep the lines connected.

Step 3
When you feel you have generated enough material through free association, look at the result: all your ideas spread across one page. 
As you examine your mind map, you will see relationships that help you organize and integrate your ideas. 
Look for words that appear repeatedly throughout map. They often suggest major themes.

Step 4
Connect related parts of your mind map with arrows, codes, and colors. 
Eliminate elements that seem extraneous. Pare your mind map down to just the ideas you need for your purpose. 
Then put them in sequence, if necessary. This can be accomplished with numbers or by redrawing the mind map in clockwise order.

How Do You Know When You Are Finished
title: Pws Notes (Part 146)

content:
Theoretically, a mind map never ends. As Da Vinci emphasized, “Everything is connected to everything else.” 
If you had the time, energy, inclination, enough colored pens, and a big enough piece of paper, you could go on linking all your knowledge and ultimately all human knowledge. 
Of course, if you are planning a speech or studying for an examination, you probably don’t have time to link all human knowledge. 
The simple answer is that your mind map is finished when the information you have generated meets your objectives for the task at hand.

Defining MECE
MECE is a list.  It is a list of qualities lists should have.  [MECE] says that when data from a category is desired to be broken into subcategories, the choice of subcategories should be
collectively exhaustive — i.e., the set of all subcategories, taken together, should fully characterize the larger category of which the data are part (“no gaps”)
mutually exclusive — i.e., no subcategory should represent any other subcategory (“no overlaps”)
This is desirable for the purpose of analysis: mutual exclusivity avoids the risk of double counting information, and collective exhaustion avoids the risk of overlooking information. In plain English, MECE says that a list should have
No overlaps
No gaps
MECE
Mutually Exclusive: The branches of the tree don't overlap, or contain partial elements of the same factor or component. This is a little hard to get your head around, but it means that the core concept of each trunk or branch of the problem is self‐contained, not spread across several branches. 
Collectively Exhaustive:  Taken as a whole, your tree contains all of the elements of the problem, not just some of them. If you are missing parts, you may very well miss the solution to your problem.

logic trees and

The 80/20 RULE
title: Pws Notes (Part 149)

content:
To Find Competitive Advantage
The Pareto Principle (also known as the “80/20 Rule” or the “Law of the Vital Few”) states that, for many events, roughly 80% of the effects come from 20% of the causes. It results from a ‘power law’ distribution.  Examples of this principle: 
Wealth: The top 20% of the population own more than 80% of the nation's wealth.
Science: The top 20% of published papers account for more than 80% of all cited works in subsequent publications.
Computing: Fixing the top 20% of the most-reported bugs eliminates 80% of errors and crashes in a given system.
Entertainment: The top 20% of titles make up more than 80% of viewers/listeners.
80/20 Rule Thinking
“80/20” Thinking is Counterintuitive 
We tend to expect that all causes have roughly the same consequences. Examples:

In Business: That all customers are equally valuable; that every product, every sales dollar, every geography is as good as any other. That each employee in the same category is roughly as good as the other.

In Our Lives: That each day or week or year we spend has roughly the same significance. That each of our friends and social activities have roughly the same value to us. Or, conversely, that most of our joys or frustrations are contributed roughly equally by each of them.

In Our Careers: That our classes, and concepts taught, have roughly the same value to us. That all opportunities that present themselves hold similar promise for the future.
title: Pws Notes (Part 150)

content:
In Problem Solving: That problems have a large number of causes, so it is not worth isolating a few causes.

Application of the 80/20 Rule
The 80/20 Principle Turns Conventional Thinking Upside Down.  Application of the principle means that we should do the following:
Promote exceptional productivity rather than raising average efforts. This has  implications for organizations (e.g., personnel decisions), business line/product development choices, as well as deciding on one’s own objectives and activities.

Be selective, not exhaustive. Strive for excellence in a few things rather than good performance in many.

Delegate as much as possible in order to focus effort

In every sphere of importance, look for the vital few actions that will yield the great majority of returns (E.g., Warren Buffett’s 20 investment decisions).

Calm down, work less, and think more. (Be ready not to do what is expected of you.)

Do what comes naturally and you enjoy. But: Find the highest value domain in which to do it. (E.g.,Ronald Reagan was an actor that applied his skills to government)

Good Issue Trees Meet MECE and 80/20 Rule
The Point
The point of doing 80/20 analyses is again to focus your analytical effort on the most important factors.
Example: Solving the Problem of Medication Errors
A medication error is a failure in the treatment process that leads to, or has the potential to lead to, harm to the patient. 
Per the NIH, recent studies of medical errors have estimated errors may account for as many as 251,000 deaths annually in the United States, making medical errors the third leading cause of death. 
Error rates are significantly higher in the U.S. than in other developed countries such as Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Germany and the United Kingdom. At the same time less than 10 percent of medical errors are reported. 
Example: Medication Errors
Per the WHO, there is no consensus about the definition of a medication error. A systematic literature review found 26 different terminologies employed for a medication error.
Medication errors can occur in 
deciding which medicine and dosage regimen to use (prescribing faults—irrational, inappropriate, and ineffective prescribing, underprescribing, overprescribing); 
writing the prescription (prescription errors); manufacturing the formulation (wrong strength, contaminants or adulterants, wrong or misleading packaging); 
dispensing the formulation (wrong drug, wrong formulation, wrong label); 
administering or taking the medicine (wrong dose, wrong route, wrong frequency, wrong duration); monitoring therapy (failing to alter therapy when required, erroneous alteration). 
They can be classified, using a psychological classification of errors, as knowledge-, rule-, action- and memory-based errors. 
Although medication errors can occasionally be serious, they are not commonly so and are often trivial. However, it is important to detect them, since system failures that result in minor errors can later lead to serious errors.

title: Pws Notes (Part 153)

content:
Finding the Root Cause: The Five Why’s
The vehicle did not start. (the problem)
Why
 - The battery is dead. (First why)
Why
 - The alternator is not functioning. (Second why)
Why
 - The alternator belt has broken. (Third why)
Why
 - The alternator belt was well beyond its useful service life and not replaced. (Fourth why)
Why
 - The vehicle was not maintained according to the recommended service schedule. (Fifth why, a root cause)
The questioning for this example could be taken further to a sixth, seventh, or higher level, but five iterations of asking why is generally sufficient to get to a root cause. The key is to encourage the trouble-shooter to avoid assumptions and logic traps and instead trace the chain of causality in direct increments from the effect through any layers of abstraction to a root cause that still has some connection to the original problem. Note that, in this example, the fifth why suggests a broken process or an alterable behaviour, which is indicative of reaching the root-cause level.
It is interesting to note that the last answer points to a process. This is one of the most important aspects in the 5 Why approach - the real root cause should point toward a process that is not working well or does not exist. Untrained facilitators will often observe that answers seem to point towards classical answers such as not enough time, not enough investments, or not enough manpower. These answers may be true, but they are out of our control. Therefore, instead of asking the question why
, ask why did the process fail

Example
An outcome statement must at a minimum contain a direction of improvement, a unit of measure to indicate what must be measured and controlled to improve the level of satisfaction and an object of control. Optionally, an outcome statement may contain a contextual clarifier to describe the conditions or circumstances under which the outcome needs to be achieved and examples that clarify, when needed, the object of control. 
The statement is structured such that the requirement’s satisfaction is measurable. If it can be measured, it can be controlled. When it comes to getting a job done better, a company must be able to quantify the degree to which customer satisfaction is being improved by a new or improved product or service concept. This makes it possible to act on the requirement. 
To limit variability from statement to statement, we suggest that each statement begin with either the word “minimize” or “increase.”
title: Pws Notes (Part 157)

content:
Summary: Mapping Outcomes
With the core functional job defined, the next step is to create a “job map” for that job. A job map is a visual depiction of the core functional job, deconstructed into its discrete process or job steps, which explains in detail exactly what the customer is trying to get done. 
A job map does not show what the customer is doing (a solution view); rather, it describes what the customer is trying to get done (a needs view).
﻿
A desired outcome statement includes a direction of improvement, a performance metric (usually time or likelihood), an object of control (the desired outcome), and a contextual clarifier (describing the context in which the outcome is desired). “Minimize the likelihood that the music sounds distorted when played at high volume” is one example of an outcome statement related to the job of listening to music. When creating a desired outcome statement, remember the following structure: Outcome statement = direction of improvement + performance metric + object of control + contextual clarifier 
Desired outcome statements can be uncovered using any of the popular interviewing methods, such as personal interviews, focus groups, or observational or ethnographic interviews. 
While most qualitative research has a short shelf life, a complete set of desired outcome statements is an important company asset for years to come as desired outcomes don’t change over time—the solutions that address them do. With a complete set of desired outcome statements in hand, a company can gain quantitative insights into its market

The Methodology
"When you’re stuck with a tough decision or a problem you don’t understand, talk to all the smart people you know." It’s the networking approach to problem solving….we have a well-developed and continuously refined methodology; 
Understand the market, the client, the technology, and the perceived constraints on the problem. Later in a project, we often challenge those constraints, but it’s important to understand current perceptions. 
Observe real people in real-life situations to find out what makes them tick: what confuses them, what they like, what they hate, where they have latent needs not addressed by current products and services
Visualize new-to-the-world concepts and the customers who will use them. Some people think of this step as predicting the future, and it is probably the most brainstorming-intensive phase of the process. Quite often, the visualization takes the form of a computer-based rendering or simulation, though IDEO also builds thousands of physical models and prototypes every year. For new product categories we sometimes visualize the customer experience by using composite characters and storyboard-illustrated scenarios. In some cases, we even make a video that portrays life with the future product before it really exists. 
Evaluate and refine the prototypes in a series of quick iterations. We try not to get too attached to the first few prototypes, because we know they’ll change. No idea is so good that it can’t be improved upon, and we plan on a series of improvements. We get input from our internal team, from the client team, from knowledgeable people not directly involved with the project, and from people who make up the target market. We watch for what works and what doesn’t, what confuses people, what they seem to like, and we incrementally improve the product in the next round. 
Implement the new concept for commercialization. This phase is often the longest and most technically challenging in the development process, but I believe that IDEO’s ability to successfully implement lends credibility to all the creative work that goes before.
title: Pws Notes (Part 162)

content:
Seven Secrets for Better Brainstorming
SHARPEN THE FOCUS  Good brainstormers start with a well-honed statement of the problem…. Go for something tangible that participants can sink their teeth into, without limiting the possible solutions. We’ve also found that the best topic statements focus outward on a specific customer need or service enhancement rather than focusing inward on some organizational goal. 
PLAYFUL RULES  Don’t start to critique or debate ideas. 
NUMBER YOUR IDEAS  We’ve found that a hundred ideas per hour usually indicates a good, fluid brainstorming session. 
BUILD AND JUMP  Try building on an idea. Encourage another push or introduce a small variation. Or take a jump, either back to an earlier path you skipped by too quickly or forward to a completely new approach. Whatever you do, try to get into the next power curve and keep the energy up,
THE SPACE REMEMBERS  Great brainstorm leaders understand the power of spatial memory. Write the flow of ideas down in a medium visible to the whole group. 
STRETCH YOUR MENTAL MUSCLES  One type of warm-up we practice is a fast-paced word game simply to clear the mind…. Another warm-up is to do some content-related homework. 
GET PHYSICAL  Good brainstorms are extremely visual. They include sketching, mind mapping, diagrams, and stick figures. 
SYSTEMATIC INVENTIVE THINKING
DREW BOYD AND JACOB GOLDENBERG
THINKING INSIDE THE BOX
(SIMON & SCHUSTER: 2013)
title: Pws Notes (Part 163)

content:
Thinking Inside the Box
The traditional view of creativity is that it is unstructured and doesn’t follow rules or patterns. That you need to think “outside the box” to be truly original and innovative. That you should start with a problem and then “brainstorm” ideas without restraint until you find a solution. That you should “go wild” making analogies to things that have nothing to do with your products, services, or processes. That straying as far afield as possible will help you come up with a breakthrough idea. We believe just the opposite. We’ll show you that more innovation— and better and quicker innovation— happens when you work inside your familiar world (yes, inside the box) using what we call templates. …the majority of new, inventive, and successful products result from only five templates: 
subtraction, 
division, 
multiplication, 
task unification, and 
attribute dependency. 
These templates form the basis of the innovation method called Systematic Inventive Thinking (SIT).
title: Pws Notes (Part 164)

content:
The Five Templates
SUBTRACTION.  Innovative products and services often have had something removed, usually something that was previously thought to be essential to the product or service. 
DIVISION.  Many creative products and services have had a component divided out of them and placed somewhere else in the usage situation, usually in a way that initially seemed unproductive or unworkable. 
MULTIPLICATION.  With this technique, a component has been copied but changed in some way, usually in a way that initially seemed unnecessary or odd. 
TASK UNIFICATION.  With some creative products and services, certain tasks have been brought together and unified within one component of the product or service— usually a component that was previously thought to be unrelated to that task. 
ATTRIBUTE DEPENDENCY.  In many innovative products and services, two or more attributes that previously seemed unrelated now correlate with one another. As one thing changes, something else changes.
title: Pws Notes (Part 165)

content:
Using these techniques correctly relies on two key principles. The first is called the “Closed World” principle. We’ve actually introduced it to you already: the notion that the best and fastest way to innovate is to look at resources close at hand. 
The second principle requires retraining how your brain thinks about problem solving. Most people assume that the way to innovate is to start with a well-defined problem and then try to think of solutions. In our method, it is just the opposite. We start with an abstract, conceptual solution and then work back to the problem that it solves. Therefore, we have to learn how to reverse the usual way our brain works when innovating.
title: Pws Notes (Part 166)

content:
The Closed World
We believe that you’ll be most creative when you focus on the internal aspects of a situation or problem— and when you constrain your options rather than broaden them. By defining and then closing the boundaries of a particular creative challenge and then looking only inside these boundaries, you can be more creative more consistently than by musing about the stratosphere or, worse, waiting for the muse to descend. 
The Closed World is based on the idea that you look inward rather than outward, and that this propels you toward the virgin territory of truly creative ideas— ideas that are both original and useful. …these ideas all satisfied two conditions: 
First, they contradicted some essential belief in the prevailing wisdom about the right way to do things. 
Second, all the solutions were contained in a relatively small space surrounding the problem. …the Closed World of the problem.
…our Closed World principle says that the further you go from the problem, the less creative you will be. 
Which brings us to another important point: the purpose of the Closed World is to teach creativity first and foremost. It’s not to always come up with the best solution to a problem at hand. Sometimes the best solution to a problem can actually be found outside the box. But if your goal is to systematize creativity, you have to operate within the confines of the Closed World. That is key. 
…by limiting the number of variables under consideration from infinity to a finite number, we amplify our potential to come up with a creative solution. Why
 Such limits boost the creative process, allowing individuals to be more focused. 
Perhaps when people eliminate resources and pare down their problem world to its basic elements, they tap into their own natural resourcefulness. Creativity is really about an intelligent search among a limited list of possibilities, rather than random, long-distance outward leaps and bounds. This, then, is our first rule: look inside!

Peter Thiel’s View
Under perfect competition, in the long run no company makes an economic profit. The opposite of perfect competition is monopoly. Whereas a competitive firm must sell at the market price, a monopoly owns its market, so it can set its own prices. Since it has no competition, it produces at the quantity and price combination that maximizes its profits. 
…by “monopoly,” we mean the kind of company that’s so good at what it does that no other firm can offer a close substitute. Google is a good example of a company that went from 0 to 1: it hasn’t competed in search since the early 2000s, when it definitively distanced itself from Microsoft and Yahoo!
title: Pws Notes (Part 168)

content:
Every monopoly is unique, but they usually share some combination of the following characteristics: proprietary technology, network effects, economies of scale, and branding.
As a good rule of thumb, proprietary technology must be at least 10 times better than its closest substitute in some important dimension to lead to a real monopolistic advantage. Anything less than an order of magnitude better will probably be perceived as a marginal improvement and will be hard to sell, especially in an already crowded market. The clearest way to make a 10x improvement is to invent something completely new.

Every startup is small at the start. Every monopoly dominates a large share of its market. Therefore, every startup should start with a very small market. Always err on the side of starting too small. The reason is simple: it’s easier to dominate a small market than a large one. If you think your initial market might be too big, it almost certainly is.

A Taxonomy of Problems
Our approach is based on the idea that there are three different kinds of problems across three different time horizons
What is possible, and what is plausible, what is probable, 
What we have called un-defined, ill-defined, and well-defined
Each kind of problem asks different kinds of questions, requires different kinds of tools, different kinds of “solutions,” and different kinds of business cases.
Examples: Different Kinds of Questions

Well-defined problems are problems as we normally think of them
What the solution needs to accomplish is clear, even if it is hard to do
Ill-defined problems, by contrast, ask what is the next big thing for us here, in this specific technological or market space
The “solution” is a list of opportunities because lots of things could serve as the next big thing
The goal is to create that list and then figure out what exactly to work on
And lastly, un-defined problems ask questions about what the future will look like
This is not a problem in the normal sense of the word
Rather it is a description of future states which can be explored for problems worth working on; 
Problems that help us create a list of opportunities that that can be used to prepare for, or even create, a future we want
To summarize, only well-defined problems can be solved in the traditional sense of the word because only there can the solution be falsified – it works or it doesn’t
By contrast, ill- and un-defined problems are used to create portfolios of opportunities – the distinction is critical
The problem here is that all too often we treat all problems as well-defined and use the wrong tools.
And an even bigger problem is that that the “next big thing” almost always comes from un-defined and ill-defined problems, while the funding always comes from well-defined problems

title: Pws Notes (Part 187)

content:
READ FROM SLIDE
Uncertainty is not risk
Risk is the probability of loss, injury, or other adverse outcome. It can be estimated and calculated based on our knowledge of prior outcomes and conditions. It has been mathematically formulated since the late 17th century, notably in the work of Blaise Pascal. Most importantly, it can be managed. Risk can be distributed (syndicated), insured against, hedged, and reduced. In short, it can be quantified and controlled.
Uncertainty is different. It is not subject to exact quantification. It was only recently formalized in the early 20th century work of the economist Frank Knight. It represents all of the possible future states of the world at any given time. The higher the uncertainty, the greater the number of possible outcomes, both positive and negative. It is a source of discomfort because we cannot predict it, but it is also a source of potential value. Higher uncertainty means greater potential, and most of us underestimate the extent of that potential since there are more possible future states of the world than we can possibly comprehend.
While some view the two as essentially the same and use the words interchangeably, uncertainty is quite distinct from risk, both in its character and in its use. In fact, what sets highly successful entrepreneurs and innovators apart from the rest of the population is the ability to see and use this difference as the basis for their success. The good news is that we can learn from them.
Btw, this distinction is also why most companies want to size existing markets -- if you have heard the expression "TAM" or "SAM" (total addressable market, or serviceable addressable market), these are measures of existing, known, markets, since one can numerically estimate the current size of these. My corporate clients often ask me to help them estimate these sizes.    
Entrepreneurs on the other hand discover entirely new markets -- there is no "addressable market" until they do what Drucker famously said in Innovation and Entrepreneurship, which is, to "create a customer."  Once we know there are customers for, say, hula hoops or carbonated drinks or spreadsheets, only then can we create an estimate of a TAM.
We manage risk, but exploit uncertainty
Entrepreneurs and innovators see value in uncertainty since they earn profits when gains are appreciably greater than is generally expected.

content:
METHOD 2: SCENARIO ANALYSIS
How to Use Scenario Analysis
Scenario analysis is a second technique we use to think differently about the future
Again, this is the entire point of un-defined problems
The key idea here (and really of both techniques) is that we are not predicting what the future will be, but describing alternative possible futures that are rooted in what is actually happening now
Trend analysis is straightforward – take a trend, carry it forward, and see if anything interesting shows up
Scenario analysis is different – it is more formal
It posits a set of possible futures, but attaches no probabilities
It creates stories along known dimensions 
READ THE SLIDE – this is the way we create scenarios
Not the Nine Box Matrix
Scenario analysis is not some version of the 9-box matrix, a popular HR tool used to measure employee performance and to identify employees with leadership potential, created by McKinsey in 1970
It was later adapted by GE to identify key investments and to compare various business units
The problem is that probability and impact can really only be measured for low uncertainty opportunities
By contrast, scenario analysis is not a predictive tool, but a descriptive tool by which we create alternative futures that can then be explored for problems and opportunities
Example: The Future of Education
Let’s take an example
What is the future of education
How would you even begin answering that
One way is a trend analysis – what will the world look like if we never return to traditional classrooms
Or, what will the world look like if we are all taught by robots
With scenario analysis, we build four possible, but distinct futures, and then ask what we might find, or not find, there
The key starting step is choice of axes – you can see several possibilities on the slide
A good place to get axes is from a trend analysis
The point is that there is no perfect way to do scenarios – the only good answer is one that you find useful
Very important – the scenarios need to mirror each other
Scenario Analysis for Education
These are the two axes that we chose – delivery method (virtual or in-person) and method of instruction (a real teacher or a robot with AI)
You will notice that scenarios are given descriptive names, usually accompanied by pictures
Descriptions of the Scenarios
The next step is to actually write the descriptions
In general, this would require real research and an analysis of current trends
Extremely important – the scenarios need to mirror each other, i.e. the same kind of stuff needs to be in each box
Opportunities from Scenario Analysis
The last step is to then search each scenario for the interesting problems that might be found in such a future – take a look at the ones on the slide
Problems are, of course, opportunities; and the key is to find the most interesting opportunities that could actually be started today
A simple way of thinking about this is to ask what kinds of products and services and policies will be needed if this future comes to pass

Systems give us another way to think about un-defined problems and escape from presentism

content:
ILL-DEFINED PROBLEMS
Problem Types
Innovation begins with finding problems worth solving
Our point is that there are different kinds of problems with different time horizons, different degrees of uncertainty and risk, and they cannot be addressed or “solved” in all the same way
Un-defined problems are addressed by exploring possible futures and seeing what kinds of problems might be found there that can be addressed starting today
Ill-defined problems are still traditional in the sense that they are present forward; by contrast, un-defined problems are future backward
Ill-Defined Problems
Ill-defined problems look at what is plausible in a technology or market space or customer experience in order to find the next big problem worth working on
The point is that many, many things could answer the question, “What’s the next big thing
”
And like un-defined problems, ill-defined problems help us create a portfolio of innovation
Example: What’s Next Big Thing for Electric Vehicles
Ill-defined problems are not about imagining distant futures, but operate on a shorter time horizon and ask “What’s the next big thing here, in this specific space
”
For example, the question on this slide is not “What’s the future of electric vehicles
” but what’s the next big thing for anyone who will use or manufacture them
Example: Baltimore Harbor
Here is an example
It all began when students went down to the Baltimore Harbor and were shocked by the amount of pollution they saw there; and decided they wanted to do something 
Let’s be clear – they did not ask about future state of the harbor
Rather, the question they asked themselves was how to clean up pollution in waterways
The possibilities are near endless
Framing an Ill-Defined Problem
Which is what makes it an ill-defined problem – there is no single solution for the simple reason that there is no clearly defined problem yet that can be solved
Something is missing; something is needed to constrain the problem
Supplying those constraints is what then allows us to begin building the lists that are the “answer” to an ill-defined problem
It is the ability to drive the creation of such lists that represents the true power of ill-defined problems (as well as un-defined problems)
And from that list you pick the ones you want to work on
The Process for Creating an Ill-Defined Problem
So the first thing the students did to address this ill-defined space was to supply the missing elements by clarifying what kind of waterway, and what kind of pollution
They decided to focus on trash in inland waterways
And then they made lists of opportunities using a set of tools and techniques
And the lists were quite extensive – similar to the DTA example on the first day
The Solution
Then they picked one opportunity and turned it into a well-defined problem
In this case – how to continuously clean up trash from inland waterways with minimal human intervention and oversight
 – what you see here
They designed and built a robot that uses AI and computer vision to clean up the harbor – something like a water-based Roomba
This is a well-defined problem because whatever solution they built either worked or it did not – the solution was falsifiable
The PixieDrone
And, of course, they were years ahead of their time – there are now lots of companies out there chasing the students’ idea, for example the one you see here
Over the years, our students have probably left hundreds of millions of dollars worth of funding on the table from all the good ideas they have chosen not to pursue
Summary: Using Ill-Defined Problems
To summarize, ill-defined problems are very different from un-defined problems
They do not ask about future states in a very uncertain world, but simply what is plausibly the next big thing inherent in this particular situation
And the key is that there is no single answer; in fact, many things could actually address the “problem”
Hence, we make lists
Like un-defined problems, ill-defined problems can help us create a bank of interesting opportunities
From which we can then select the best ones and turn them into well-defined problems that can actually be solved

Two Kinds of Innovation
A good way of thinking about extensive searching comes from a book by Frans Johansson, where he describes “intersectional ideas,” a theory that he developed by asking why the Renaissance was such an extraordinarily creative period
Intersectional Ideas
Johansson claims that there are two kinds of ideas:
Directional ideas are where we know where we are going, and
Intersectional ideas, where we don’t know where we are going, and are often the product of serendipity
Characteristics
Intersectional ideas are where we put two things together in surprising, unusual, non-obvious, and fascinating ways.
The key is that the combination is unexpected
But this is the way the world has always progressed, and the way technology has always advanced
Everything “new” is really just a new combination of existing ideas; because no “new thing” comes out of nothing

The Technology Complex
Let’s look at one category of changes in more detail – technology and science
First it must be remembered that technology is not a simple thing, but represents a complex
Think of all that is involved in using an induction stove, or a solar panel, or an electric vehicle, or tele-medicine
Technological Transitions
As these complexes change over time, they undermine the competitive advantages of existing firms
Diminishing Returns
But as technologies mature, they experience ever diminishing returns
Technology S-Curves
Technological changes and transitions can be thought of as s-curves, where improvement in the technology per unit of input diminishes over time
In other words, technological improvement runs up against barriers, either physical or market, and that is when opportunities for disruptive innovations present themselves
So here is the question, where are technologies reaching their limit
 
For example, how much more power can they build into your phone before you stop caring, and stop wanting to pay for it
An Evolutionary Process
In other words, technological change can be thought of as an evolutionary process where a long series of small changes is abruptly ended by a big change
Big changes lead to what are called technological discontinuities, which create enormous opportunities for innovators
Macro and Micro-Inventions
Another way to think about this is in terms of micro-and macro-inventions
Micro-inventions can be explained by basic economics and marketing
Who wins at micro-changes – incumbent players
Who often wins at macro-changes – disruptive companies
The real question is where macro-inventions come from – you can improve a wagon all you want, but you will never get a car.  
Macro changes are often intersectional ideas (a new combination of things)
For example, cars come from combining wagons and internal combustion engines.
Dominant Designs
Macro- and micro-changes can be combined in the model you see here
Technological change can be thought of as an evolutionary process where a long series of small changes is abruptly ended by a big change
Big changes lead to what are called technological discontinuities, which ultimately create what are called dominant designs
So what is a dominant design

Wicked Problems
Food insecurity in West Africa is a classic example of what is called a wicked problem is a social or cultural problem that's difficult or impossible to solve because of its complex and interconnected nature, specifically for the four reasons that you see here
Characteristics of Wicked Problems
The term “wicked problem” came into common use in the 1970s, and has the characteristics that you see here
Based on these characteristics, not all hard-to-solve problems are wicked, only those with an indeterminate scope and scale. 
So most social problems—such as inequality, political instability, death, disease, or famine—are wicked.
The indeterminate scope and scale make wicked problems into what we would call a type of ill-defined problem
And as we will see, the way to address them is to create a list of opportunities

Wicked problems need to be understood as a type of systems problem

We will now take a more formal look at systems problems
So what is a system – a system is an interconnected set of elements that is coherently organized in a way that achieves something
Therefore, all systems have three components – elements, interconnections, and a purpose
Implications
