1. health and well-being.
2. life at home.
3. play and entertainment.
4. shopping and consumption.
5. learning.
6. work.
7. communication and information.
8. travel and mobility.
9. the battlefield.
10. space.

These are all fascinating questions. The specific domain researched is really a matter of student interest and taste.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 51)

content:
Scenario analysis represents a technique for exploring un-defined spaces and imagining alternative futures. Rather than take a single trend and carry it to its absurd conclusion, scenario analysis helps us create “stories of the future,” all of which are possible and which allow us to ask “What problems might confront us in a future
 Where are the opportunities
 What are the best problems to work on now
”

Part I

1.      Choose a domain of interest to you.

2.      Research the space and identify trends.

3.      Use the trends to prepare a list of possible axes.

4.      Choose the two you think will be most fruitful.

·       Iterate as necessary

5.      Create a 2x2 scenario analysis:

·       Step one: label the scenarios and use pictures

·       Step two: flesh out the scenarios and create parallel story lines

Part II

6.      Focus on the scenario(s) that seems to be most the most interesting (e.g., the one that makes you most uncomfortable)

7.      Explore the scenario(s) for opportunities:

·       What is missing in this future

·       What products, services, and policies will be needed

8.      Conclusion: What problems will we find in the future
  What opportunities are worth working on today

---

To summarize, the process for using Scenario Analysis as a technique for innovation is as follows:

***Systems Analysis***

SIDEBAR ON RUSSELL ACKOFF

---
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 52)

content:
Systems analysis and systems thinking are vast subjects. And we will not do them justice here. While systems thinking has distant origins in ancient times and across many different cultures, our ideas have been heavily influenced by the work of Russell Ackoff.[[6]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

A system is most easily understood as an interconnected set of elements that is coherently organized in a way that achieves something. Is there anything that is not a system
 Yes—a conglomeration without any particular interconnections or function. Sand scattered on a road by happenstance is not, itself, a system.[[7]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

What is important for us is that systems thinking and systems analysis give us another way of exploring un-defined problems and confronting the challenge of presentism. We will not attempt to arbitrarily distinguish between the two; suffice it to say that both are rooted in systems theory which can be defined as
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 53)

content:
the trans-disciplinary study of systems, i.e. cohesive groups of interrelated, interdependent components that can be natural or human-made. Every system has causal boundaries, is influenced by its context, defined by its structure, function and role, and expressed through its relations with other systems. A system is "more than the sum of its parts" by expressing synergy or emergent behavior.

The goals of systems theory are to model a system's dynamics, constraints, conditions, and relations; and to elucidate principles (such as purpose, measure, methods, tools) that can be discerned and applied to other systems ***at every level of nesting***….[[8]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

SIDEBAR ON RUSSIAN MATRYOSHKA DOLLS

---

In other words, systems can be embedded in systems, which are embedded in yet other systems, what are called nested hierarchies. A nested hierarchy is “a hierarchical ordering of nested sets.  The concept of nesting is exemplified in Russian matryoshka dolls. Each doll is encompassed by another doll, all the way to the outer doll.[[9]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 54)

content:
It is probably safe to say that all systems have some sort of nested hierarchy, going from the most basic elements all the way up to big, all-inclusive paradigms. Although we will look at systems again later in this book, we will focus here on how the concept of nested hierarchies can help us explore un-defined problems.

Nested hierarchies are everywhere, in both the natural world and the man-made world. Here are some simple examples:

1. cell à heart, arteries, veins à circulatory system à person
2. battle à campaign à war à national policy
3. student à class à grade à school à school district à national educational system

Nested hierarchies can be understood as parts and a whole, i.e., a system. Systems are not random collections of parts, and all systems must consist of three kinds of things:

1. elements,
2. interconnections, and
3. a function or purpose.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 55)

content:
Systems are more than the sum of their parts. Systems may exhibit adaptive, dynamic, goal-seeking, self-preserving, and sometimes evolutionary behavior;[[10]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) where the goals and behavior of each part do not necessarily align with the goals and behavior of the whole. Therefore, the interconnections among the parts, as well as among the parts and the whole, go a long way toward explaining the behavior of the system; not to mention the “success” of the system in achieving its stated goals. To state the obvious, improving the performance of one part does not necessarily improve the performance of the whole. And, in fact, the parts may not even care about the performance of the whole.

SIDEBAR ON THE HISTORY OF SUBMARINES

---

As an example, suppose you had been a flag officer of the United States Navy in the first decade of the 20th century and had been tasked with the following question – “What is the future of submarine warfare
” Clearly an un-defined problem, in the sense of enquiring about future states rather than seeking to develop specific solutions. Since the middle of the 16th century, inventors had been designing and building submarines for demonstration, even though they were actually “submersibles” rather than true submarines. But no matter.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 56)

content:
The first ship sunk by a submarine was the Union sloop *USS Housatonic*, destroyed by the Confederacy’s *CSS Hunley* in 1864.[[11]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) The very short career of the *CSS Hunley* (she was sunk in 1864) left naval planners cautious. Although the development of self-propelled torpedoes in the last decades of the 19th century promised to make the submarine (as well as the torpedo boat) a more effective weapon of war, by the outbreak of WWI, the role of submarines in overall naval strategy was as unclear as was their tactical handling.

The only things that could be safely assumed by our flag officer in the first decade of the 20th century was that the number and range of submarines deployed by all Great Powers was increasing, and would likely continue to increase. So how would you go about your task
 You could ask long-serving naval officers, but that would likely confront you rather quickly with the problem of presentism. You could try to work out a scenario analysis.

Or you could start with *Trending to the Absurd*. Which would force you to confront a world with thousands of submarines cruising the world’s oceans and waterways and then ask what naval strategy and government policy might look. With this question, you could then think about submarines as a system, more specifically in terms of nested hierarchies. Take a look at this diagram:
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 57)

content:
The place of submarines within the nested hierarchy shown here is fairly clear. The implications are less so, for example:

1. **Sailors** – They need to be trained and led. What will a submarine corps look like

2. **Submarine** **subsystems** – How can the individual subsystems be made to work together more effectively

3. **Submarine** – How can the overall performance of the submarine be improved
)
4. **Battle or campaign** – ****How should submarines be armed, deployed, and resupplied to achieve maximum effect

5. What should the **national policy** be for their employment
 E.g., should they attack civilian ships
 Should commerce or warships be the main focus of naval strategy

Very simply, there is no good way to answer the question, “What is the future of submarine warfare
” without thinking in terms of systems and nested hierarchies.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 58)

content:
For example, suppose your engineering team decided to improve the periscope, how would that impact the future of submarine warfare, even as it might impact the overall “performance” of the submarine, however defined. How might this improvement in the periscope impact the handling of a submarine in a battle. For example, should submarines attack under the surface with torpedoes or on the surface with their guns once they have approached a surface ship surreptitiously. Or, how can submarines communicate with each other as well as with surface ships and aircraft
 At the top of the pyramid, how would these innovations impact the future of submarine warfare as an instrument of naval strategy and national policy.

Remembering that our objective here is not a strategy paper, but opportunities for innovation, we need to get beyond thinking of submarines as isolated “things-in-themselves.” Rather, they are part of a system comprising interlocking elements, connections, and purposes, all of which can be explored for opportunities; i.e., for the products, services, and policies that will be needed to make the elements, interlocking connections, and purposes all work better. For example:

1. How can sailors and subsystems be made more efficient/effective/productive within the system

2. How can subsystems be made to work better to improve the overall performance of the submarine
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 59)

content:
3. How can communications and interactions among submarines, and with the rest of the navy, be made more effective

4. How can the purpose/meaning of naval warfare be re-imagined

To summarize, un-defined problems ask about future states and give us the opportunity to imagine alternative futures that can be explored for innovation opportunities. In this case, a world where there are thousands of submarines, possibly with the power to overwhelm capital ships and choke off global commerce.

Here are some more examples that we use in class. What is the future of

1. teen mental health
2. fake meat
3. schools
4. care for disabled adults
5. news
6. recycling
7. eldercare
8. social media
9. marriage
10. cities
11. office buildings

These are all fascinating questions. The specific domain researched is really a matter of student interest and taste.

Systems analysis allows us to put the domain of interest into a broader, more strategic, context; just as it forces us to consider not merely the efficiency of the elements, but the effectiveness of the relationships among the elements, as well as the relevance of any purpose claimed by the whole. Systems analysis and nested hierarchies represent one more technique for exploring un-defined spaces and for imagining how things might be different in an alternative future: “What problems might confront us in a future
 Where are the opportunities
 What are the best problems to work on now
”
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 60)

content:
To summarize, the process for using *Systems Analysis and Nested Hierarchies* is as follows:

1.      Choose a domain of interest to you. Ask “What is the future of…
”

2.      Identify the key elements in that domain

3.      Place the domain within a larger system of nested hierarchies

·       Prepare a systems map showing the hierarchies

4.      Identify relevant trends in that domain

·       What is changing and how fast

·       Show your research

5.      Take one trend and carry it to its absurd conclusion

·       What are the implications for the rest of the system

6.      Where are the opportunities (minimum 3) to improve the overall performance of the domain of interest by

·       making the elements more efficient/productive within the system;

·       making the interactions among the elements of the system more effective; and

·       re-imagining the purpose/meaning of the entire system

---

***Red Teaming***
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 61)

content:
The term red team dates back to the early 1800s, when the Prussian army began using *Kriegsspiel*, or “war gaming,” to train its officers. One group of officers would develop a battle plan, while another group would assume the role of the enemy and try to thwart it. The idea was to expose flaws or weaknesses in Prussian tactics in the safety of the war room rather than wait for them to be revealed upon the battlefield. These tabletop simulations used wooden blocks as stand-ins for military units. Because most Prussian soldiers wore blue uniforms, the home team was represented by blue game pieces. The enemy force was represented by red markers and referred to as “the red team.” It was their job to probe for weaknesses in the Prussians’ plans and strategies. The name stuck.

Hoffman, Bryce G.. Red Teaming (pp. 34-35). Crown. Kindle Edition.

---

The last technique we will look at in this section is *Red Teaming*. Its distant origins are in the position created by the Roman Catholic Church, i.e. the Devil’s Advocate, who “argued against the canonization (sainthood) of a candidate in order to uncover any character flaws or misrepresentation of the evidence favoring canonization.”[[12]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

SIDEBAR ON GROUPTHINK

---
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 62)

content:
In more modern times, its origins go back to the Prussian General Staff’s war games. And in even more modern times, the idea was revived within the context of the Rand Corporation’s simulations for the US military during the Cold War. The technique was further developed by the Israeli military in the wake of its decision-making failures before the outbreak of the Yom Kippur War in 1973, specifically to attack the problem of groupthink.[[13]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

Just as scenario analysis is now a well-known and well-established technique that we have turned to a different purpose, we will use red teaming in a slightly different way than has become the norm in the world of strategy consulting.

The advantages of red teaming include

1. challenging your plans and the assumption upon which they are based;
2. forcing you to think differently about your business and consider alternative points of view;
3. helping you scan the business environment for both threats and opportunities; and
4. helping mitigate cognitive biases and groupthink.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 63)

content:
To be clear, red teaming is **not** a substitute for planning and it is not fortune-telling. Rather, red teaming is a way of challenging assumptions, paradigms, and accepted ways of thinking. And again, critically, it is a way of challenging groupthink.[[14]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

We typically use red teaming by first asking students to name a product or service they really like. And then ask them what would be needed to drive it completely from the marketplace. The most obvious example for students these days is their smartphone. What would have to happen (or become true) for smartphones to disappear from our lives
 Here are a few more examples:

1. What would have to happen (or become true) for plastic to disappear from our lives

2. What would have to happen (or become true) for fish to disappear from our lives

3. What would have to happen (or become true) for Amazon (or any other large company) be replaced

4. What would have to happen (or become true) for us to believe the news again

5. What would have to happen (or become true) for current logistical systems to be replaced

6. What would have to happen (or become true) for current systems of agriculture to be replaced

7. How would we live if no one had access to space
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 64)

content:
Like in any traditional red teaming exercise, we are looking for students to challenge paradigms, i.e., the major products and services and policies that currently dominate our lives as well as the companies and organizations that create, sell, and deliver them.

What makes this a technique for addressing un-defined problems is the need to imagine alternative futures where these products and services no longer exist. In other words, what will the future need to look like to challenge these paradigms
 What will it take to overturn them
 What will need to be true
 What will have to happen
 What new product, services, and policies will need to be created

***Summary***

Un-defined problems give us a chance to explore alternative futures. In this chapter, we have proposed a set of four tools that allow this exploration to be done in a structured manner. The “solution” to an un-defined problem is not a solution in the normal sense of the word, i.e. a product, service, or policy that can be designed and delivered to the market or public. Rather it is an imaginatively constructed space that can be more deeply explored for ill-defined problems and the opportunities that can be discovered there.

**Chapter Five – Exploring Ill-Defined Problems**
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 67)

content:
Innovation begins with finding problems worth solving. Our point is that there are different kinds of problems with different time horizons, different degrees of uncertainty and risk, and they cannot be addressed or “solved” in all the same way. Un-defined problems are addressed by exploring possible alternative futures and seeing what kinds of problems might be found there that can be addressed starting today. In other words, we explore un-defined problems by starting with the future and looking backwards; by contrast, we will explore ill-defined problems in the more traditional sense of ***present forward***.

Ill-defined problems look at what is **plausible** in a current technology or market space or customer experience in order to find the next big problem worth working on. Many, many opportunities could answer the question, “What’s the next big thing here
” And so, as with un-defined problems, ill-defined problems help us create a portfolio of innovation.

SIDEBAR ON TYPES OF ELECTRIC VEHICLES AND THEIR HISTORY

---
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 68)

content:
Take for example, the question: *What’s Next Big Thing for Electric Vehicles
* The question is clearly not, “What is the future of electric vehicles
” We are not trying to imagine distant possible futures. Rather, we are operating on a shorter time horizon and asking, “What’s the next big thing here, **in this specific space**
” In the technological space, one obvious answer relates to battery life and size; in the market space, an obvious answer relates to available infrastructure. In short, there is no single answer to the question, “What’s the next big thing for electric vehicles
” And so we create lists of opportunities, using the tools that we will explore below.

Here is another example. A group of students wanted to do a project focused on Baltimore. One day, they took themselves down to the harbor and were simply horrified by the amount of pollution there. They did not ask, “What is the future of the Baltimore Harbor
” (clearly an un-defined problem); rather they asked, “How can we clean up the pollution in the harbor
” The possibilities are near endless, which is one of the things that make this question an ill-defined problem.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 69)

content:
Ill-defined problems, by their very nature, are missing something; i.e., something is needed to constrain the problem. Supplying those constraints is what then allows us to begin building the lists or opportunities that are the “answer” to an ill-defined problem. It is the ability to drive the creation of such lists that represents the true power of ill-defined problems.

The first thing the students did to address the problem of pollution in the Baltimore Harbor was to supply the missing elements by clarifying what kind of waterway, and what kind of pollution. For example, pollution could mean sewage, domestic effluents, industrial effluents, oil, agricultural runoff, trash, etc. While waterways could mean either the ocean or inland waterways.

The team decided to focus on how to clean up trash in inland waterways. They then did their research, used some of the tools that we will be presenting in this chapter, and created a list of opportunities (similar to the example of the Digital Triage Assistant above).
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 70)

content:
After some thought, the team selected one opportunity and turned it into a well-defined problem: “How can we continuously clean up trash from inland waterways with minimal human intervention and oversight
” This is now a well-defined problem because the criteria for success are clear. In other words, any solution is now falsifiable – either it works or it does not. A well-defined problem says nothing about how easy or difficult the solution will be to devise and build and disseminate, only what it must deliver.

They designed and built a robot that used machine learning and computer vision to clean up the harbor – something like a water-based Roomba, but one capable of distinguishing, for example, trash from dead fish. What you see here is the original prototype. The design included plans for automatically emptying the trash, automatically avoiding obstacles, automatically re-charging the battery as needed, and 24/7 use. Long after the team graduated, we saw companies develop this same kind of device.[[1]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

To summarize, we use ill-defined problems to explore a technological or market space and find the opportunities that are inherent in the situation, some of which can then be turned into well-defined problems that can actually be solved. Ill-defined problems address such questions as:

1. What’s next big thing here

2. What’s missing in the marketplace
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 71)

content:
3. How can we pivot

4. How do we disrupt our business before our competitors do

Here are some examples:

1. Technology: What big problems can blockchain address

2. User Experience: How can the doctor/patient experience be improved

3. Industry space: What’s next for smartwatches

There are two basic approaches for exploring ill-defined problems:

1. Extensive searching – a broad survey over many domains looking for connections, patterns, and intersections that may prove valuable; and
2. Intensive searching – a deep dive into a single domain, researching and exploring that domain intensively.

On the following pages, we will describe each approach in more detail and offer a set of tools appropriate for each one. In fact, this entire book can be thought of as a toolkit. And just as we learned in our shop classes in high school (yes, we had to take shop classes – metal, wood, drafting – back in the day) how to use tools one at a time, before we learned how to combine them to actually make something. So our intention is to guide you through a set of tools, one at a time, for you to use as the situation, and your own inclinations, suggest.

***Extensive Searching***
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 72)

content:
A good way of thinking about extensive searching comes from a book by Frans Johansson, where he describes “intersectional ideas,” a theory that he developed by asking why the Renaissance was such an extraordinarily creative period. In fact, much of our thinking about techniques for exploring ill-defined problems comes also from our reading of the Renaissance. Johannsson writes that

the major difference between a directional idea and an intersectional one is that we know where we are going with the former…. Directional innovation improves a product in fairly predictable steps, along a well-defined dimension…. The goal is to evolve an established idea by using refinements and adjustments. The rewards for doing so are reasonably predictable and attained relatively quickly.

Intersectional innovations, on the other hand, change the world in leaps along new directions. They usually pave the way for a new field and therefore make it possible for the people who originated them to become the leaders in the fields they created. Intersectional innovations also do not require as much expertise as directional innovation and can therefore be executed by the people you least suspect.[[2]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 73)

content:
Directional innovations make an existing product better, faster, cheaper. But they do not change the game. Intersectional ideas, by contrast, create a new game. Intersectional ideas are where we put two things together **“in** **surprising, unusual, non-obvious, and fascinating ways.”**

The key is that the combination is unexpected. According to Johansson, this is the way the world has always progressed, and the way technology has always advanced. Everything “new” is really just a new combination of existing ideas; because no “new thing” comes out of nothing.

Just think of the automobile and the smartphone. You can improve a wagon all you want, but you will never get an automobile until you combine it with an internal combustion engine. Just as you can improve a mobile phone all you want, but you will never get a smartphone until you combine your brick of a mobile phone with a computer. Or think of new fields such as computational biology and behavioral economics. Or think of the way that evolutionary theory, originating in the field of biology, has now been applied to all kinds of other fields, including history, economics, and management.

Here is another example: combining an oven with a microwave is old hat, and even combining an oven with air fryers seems kind of obvious nowadays, but what about an oven and a freezer:
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 74)

content:
Two Baltimore natives and Johns Hopkins graduates have created a smart appliance system to make it easier for families and working professionals to have a home-prepared meal without having to cook it themselves.

*Celcy* stores frozen meals on one side of the appliance, moves them to its oven side when they’re ready to be prepared, cooks the meals, and tracks users’ preferences to offer suggestions.

Users can schedule meals at a particular time and, using a mobile app, direct *Celcy* to unpack and cook meals. [[3]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

Intersectional Ideas are where we don’t know where we are going and are often the product of serendipity. The real question for us here is how we might possibly create intersectional ideas, or the opportunities to discover them serendipitously. This is the process we typically use in

1.      Start with something of importance to you.

2.      Put it together with as wide range of unrelated ideas or products or services that you can think of.

3.      What **surprising, unusual, non-obvious, and fascinating (intersectional) ideas** result from the combination

4.      Where are the opportunities

---

class:
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 75)

content:
Alternatively, we ask students to think of something of importance to them and then have them make a list of all the people they would be interested in speaking to about this something, so long as their interlocutors come from unrelated fields. They can then play a mind game with other people in the class – how could this interesting person shed light on our topic of interest

***Intensive Searching***

A more intensive approach comes from our reading of the book *The Four Lenses* by Rowan Gibson, which also comes from his research on the Renaissance. He writes that all innovation has two elements:

1. an insight, and
2. the big idea that comes from the insight.

Insight in the sense of seeing what others do not see, opportunities that they have missed. And where do these insights come from
 From four lenses:
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 76)

content:
1. **Harnessing Trends**: Recognizing the future potential of emerging developments, and using these trends to open up new opportunities.
2. **Understanding Needs**: Paying attention to issues and frustrations others have ignored, and experimenting with new solutions to problems.
3. **Challenging Orthodoxies**: Questioning deeply entrenched beliefs and assumptions (i.e. received wisdom), and exploring new and highly unconventional answers.
4. **Leveraging Resources**: Understanding our limitless capacity for redeploying skills and assets in new ways, combinations, or contexts.[[4]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

We commonly use these lenses as an organizing principle in our classes and have converted them into a set of tools and techniques that students use to explore ill-defined problems class by class (see below). The insights gained can then be used to identify opportunities, and possibly big ideas.

***Harnessing Trends***
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 77)

content:
In our opinion, at the root of all innovation is change. In the prior chapter, we took a change and carried it to its absurd end in an effort to escape presentism and imagine alternative futures that might open our eyes to new possibilities and new opportunities. In this chapter, we will explore the first of Gibson’s four lenses by “recognizing the future potential of emerging developments, and using these trends to open up new opportunities.” The key is that changes “out there” always wreck something; but out of that wreckage comes opportunities.

SIDEBAR ON HISTORY OF AMAZON

---

For example, the origin of Amazon is not in bookselling per se, but in Jeff Bezos’ observation that internet usage was growing at 2300% a year and that there were enormous opportunities for e-commerce.[[5]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) Bezos was a banker; books were simply a convenient way to begin.

Or think about Blockbuster. It is hard to explain to undergrads now how much Blockbuster changed our lives. The company did not invent movies, or tape players, or the idea of rent and return. It simply took advantage of all these trends happening “out there” and combined them with the desire of consumers to stay home and watch movies otherwise inaccessible on regular television stations.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 78)

content:
Both Amazon and Blockbuster took advantage of changing technology and consumer sentiment to create enormously successful businesses. And in Blockbuster’s case, changing technology and consumer sentiment would undo them just as quickly. Amazon did not invent e-commerce and Blockbuster did not invent the home movie experience. Rather, both companies understood what was changing, what was passing, and built businesses that could take advantage of the changes.

Change can be understood in lots of ways. Perhaps the simplest is PEST – political, economic, social, technological. Developed in the 1960’s as an “environmental scanning framework,”[[6]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) it quickly became a standard tool of strategic analysis. We find it to be a convenient way of thinking through macro-changes “out there” and then asking students what these changes are likely to destroy in our current political, economic, social, and technological frameworks.

There are many frameworks for thinking about macro-trends, as a quick search on the internet clearly demonstrates. Any or all can be used depending on the circumstances and interests of the class. Charles Kirschbaum, a colleague teaching at Insper in Sao Paulo, Brazil uses these:
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 79)

content:
1. Growing demand for **eco-friendly products**
2. The health and wellness industry is experiencing significant growth, driven by factors such as an **aging population**
3. The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the **adoption of remote work** and many employees do not want to return to face-to-face work
4. Consumers increasingly seek **personalized experiences and products**
5. Growing demand for businesses that prioritize **social and environmental impact**

Other trends that we have found useful as points of departure for discussion include AI (obviously), aging populations, advanced connectivity and the idea that every thing will be connected to every other thing, the growing economies of Asia, the growth of immersive reality, the growth of nearshoring, the growth of remote work, decreasing trust in experts, the lack of health care workers, the increasing cost of higher education, the decreasing number of teachers. The list is endless.[[7]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) But how we use these trends is always the same – what is changing, what will this change wreck, what are the opportunities that come out of the wreckage
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 80)

content:
The prospect of technological and scientific changes are particularly interesting here. But first, it is important to understand the nature of technology more deeply. There is an enormous range of thought and opinion in any attempt to define technology, often depending on the discipline under consideration; thus giving rise to problems of focus and degree of specificity.

A good definition of technology comes from John Howells: “knowledge of how to organize people and tools to achieve specific ends.”[[8]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) He then introduces the idea of the technology complex “as a device that relates the general definition of technology to its subdefinitions.”[[9]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

Critically, Howells states that the “elements within the **technology complex** have been ordered to range from the physical and artifactual to the social and the cultural. This captures the idea that there are multiple ‘levels’ within society at which people organize artifacts to create working technologies. Any or all of these elements be analyzed in a working technology – a technology ‘in use’.”[[10]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) According to Howells, the technology complex, therefore, includes:
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 81)

content:
1. Material
2. Energy source
3. Artifacts/hardware
4. Layout
5. Procedures (programs, software)
6. Knowledge/skills/qualified people
7. Work organization
8. Management techniques
9. Organizational structure
10. Cost/capital
11. Industry structure (suppliers, users, promoters)
12. Location
13. Social relations
14. Culture

Think, for example, of all that is involved in designing, building, and using a computer. How all the elements of the complex described by Howells are affected; and how, in turn, they all impact the working of a computer and its functioning in our lives. Other obvious examples include the automobile, the airplane, the smartphone, a treadmill, an oven, tele-conferencing.

SIDEBAR ON HISTORY OF THE ANTIKYTHERA DEVICE

---

Technological artefacts are not simple things, and all can be “ordered to range from the physical and artifactual to the social and the cultural.” And the same goes for innovation. Innovation can occur at any level of the complex; something like the idea of technological artefacts as part of nested hierarchies.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 82)

content:
Technology also changes over time, both the artefacts themselves and the complexes which comprise them, undermining the competitive advantages of incumbent firms. How technology transitions and evolves is a subject beyond our purposes here.[[11]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) Needless to say, how technologies change, and the drivers of change, provide opportunities to innovators.

One famous model states that “the rate of a technology’s performance improvement and the rate at which technology is adopted in the marketplace have repeatedly been shown to conform to an S-curve.”[[12]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) It is now a commonplace that technology

starts out expensive, bulky, not very widely adopted; Improvement is slow as the fundamental concepts are being figured out. A period of rapid innovation and massive adoption follows, up to a slowdown in meaningful improvement and little new customers. We’ve reached the top of the S-curve — only leaving room for a whole new technology with its own S-curve to come on top.[[13]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 83)

content:
The implication is that improvement in the technology per unit of input diminishes over time. In other words, technological improvement runs up against barriers, either physical or market, and that is when opportunities for disruptive innovations present themselves – what can be thought of as an innovation window.[[14]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

Innovation opportunities present themselves where and when technologies reach their limit. So how do you know if they have reached their limit
 Often it is in the literature, the marketing data, or simply in the air. For example, how much more power can companies build into your phone or laptop before you stop caring, and stop wanting to pay for it
 Have internal combustion engine automobiles reached the top of the S-curve
 A little closer to home, has the value of a four-year degree at an expensive private college or university reached its limit
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 84)

content:
Technological change can also be thought of as an evolutionary process where a long series of small changes is abruptly ended by a big change. Big changes lead to what are called technological discontinuities, which create enormous opportunities for innovators. Another way to think about this is in terms of micro-and macro-inventions. Micro-inventions can be explained by basic economics, marketing, and the hunt for capitalist profit. The bigger question is where macro-inventions come from – getting from a wagon to a car cannot be explained by simple economics. Macro-inventions can often be thought of as intersectional ideas (a new combination of things). For example, cars come from combining wagons and internal combustion engines.

Ideas of macro- and micro-inventions can be combined to create a model of technological change, the model you see here. The concept of a dominant design was introduced by James M. Utterback and William J. Abernathy in 1975: “A dominant design is the one that wins the allegiance of the marketplace, the one to which competitors and innovators must adhere if they hope to command significant market following.”[[15]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 85)

content:
Why does every USB stick fit into every USB port
 Why does every light bulb screw into every light bulb socket
 Why does your smartphone automatically connect to Wi-Fi
 Why does every classroom look like every other classroom
 The answer is that there is a dominant design. Dominant designs can be thought of as paradigms or standards, whether technological or economic or social or political. They are generally accepted ways of working and organizing and thinking. But at some point, they begin to fall apart. You can feel it in the air; and that is when enormous opportunities present themselves.

We get a dominant design in three ways:

1. One player wins in the marketplace and forces all the others to adopt their standard.
2. The industry gets together and comes to an agreement.
3. The government forces a standard onto the marketplace.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 86)

content:
Once a dominant design is created, changes tend to be incremental; i.e. think low uncertainty and low risk. And it is the incumbent companies that will dominate such markets.[[16]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) But when a dominant design breaks apart, we enter an era of ferment, which creates opportunities for innovators; i.e. think high uncertainty and low risk. These are the spaces we want our students exploring. Examples today include charging infrastructure for electric vehicles, the structure of higher education, primary care in medicine, the impact of AI on almost everything.

In other words, technological change can be thought of as an evolutionary process where a long series of small changes is abruptly ended by a big change; what can be thought of as a technological discontinuity, which will ultimately lead to the creation of a dominant design. This dominant design changes incrementally, improved by micro-inventions brought into the marketplace by incumbent companies. Until it all starts to break apart, opening up a high uncertainty space for innovators.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 87)

content:
But where do these discontinuities come from
 And the answer is again the macro political, economic, social, and technological trends and changes happening “out there.” They can destroy dominant designs and create opportunities. In his classic book, *Only the Paranoid Survive*, Andy Grove describes the computer industry in 1980 as “vertical,” what you see here.

But by 1995, the computer industry had become “horizontal,” with a host of new companies and new technologies and different business models. But when did it all change
 What made it all change
 How could you have seen it coming
 And how could you have taken advantage of the change
[[17]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

It is critical to recognize that dominant designs are not just technological; they can be political, economic, and social as well. They simply represent accepted, normalized, ways of doing things. And they always seem to make sense until they don’t; and always seem to be permanent until they aren’t.

SIDEBAR ON ANDY GROVE

---

Grove calls this kind of change a strategic inflection point. He describes a set of indicators of such points:[[18]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

1. Has your most dangerous competitor changed

2. Do the people you have worked with for years suddenly make no sense
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 88)

content:
3. Are there customers out there rejecting your offering for something else entirely

4. Are customers paying attention to new technologies that you are ignoring

5. Is there a growing divergence between what important competitors are saying and doing

6. Is there a growing divergence between what the corporate data systems are saying and what your people are saying, especially those working with customers

7. Are lower-level people not bringing you news anymore, i.e. are they afraid to be the bearers of bad news

8. The Christensen thesis: is there a new approach or technology out there that is capturing market share, especially in niches where you no longer compete

We would add more:

1. Is there general dis-satisfaction with the current state of things, enough so that it is a constant topic in the news and social media

2. And simply, can you feel the change in the air

This is where we ask students to identify dominant designs that they think are in the process of breaking apart, whether political, economic, social, or technological. How do you know they are breaking apart
 Where are the opportunities coming from the macro-changes driving the demise of a dominant design
 How would you find them
 And what are the implications
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 89)

content:
One popular way of trying to figure out the implications of, and the opportunities arising from, macro-changes such as the collapse of a dominant design is the *Futures Wheel*, invented by Jerome Glenn in 1971 as “a method for graphical visualization of direct and indirect future consequences of a particular change or development.”[[19]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) A random Google query quickly shows how complicated such wheels can become. For example, what kind of wheel might you end up with thinking through the implications of adopting generative AI in university classrooms

SIDEBAR ON THE HISTORY OF AUTOMOBILES AND THE RATE OF ADOPTION

---

While the Futures Wheel can certainly be helpful, we have developed a different tool. For example, what kind of futures wheel would you construct to think through the implications of changes in the adoption of different technologies
 Specifically, what might the implications be for the widescale adoption of automobiles
 Think about it like this – if you were standing in 1910, what would your futures wheel look like
 It is easy to imagine one that quickly becomes overwhelmingly complex.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 90)

content:
Instead, we have gone back to the idea of systems diagrams, which we believe offers a simpler and more effective alternative. Take a look at the diagram below. The first task is to choose a set of relevant categories. The second task is to ask how rapid adoption of automobiles might impact each category. Think in terms what will change, what will be wrecked, what new products and services and policies will be needed, what new skills will need to be learned, what other markets and industries will be impacted, etc. The goal is to ask the kinds of questions that can guide the identification of innovation opportunities.

1.      Choose a domain and macro-trend of interest to you.

2.      Identify relevant PEST categories and construct a systems diagram.

·       What is changing within each category

·       What is being destroyed

·       What dominant designs are breaking down

·       Where are the discontinuities
  What are the first, second, and third order consequences within each category

3.      What are the next big problems worth solving

4.      Where are the opportunities to build on (replace
) what is being destroyed

---

This is the process we typically use in class:

***Understanding Needs***

SIDEBAR ON THE HISTORY OF GLASSES

---
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 91)

content:
The second of Gibson’s *Four Lenses* is understanding user needs; i.e., looking for opportunities in unsatisfied user experiences, or by re-thinking the user experience completely. An interesting example here is Warby Parker, an American retailer of prescription glasses, founded 2010.[[20]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) Think about how we have traditionally bought glasses – you go to the eye doctor, get a prescription, drag your mother or best friend to the glasses store, and then agonize over what to buy. The misery of this user experience led to early attempts to bring this process online using software that never quite worked.

By contrast, Warby Parker’s approach is so simple – you order five pairs of frames to your home; and then organize a dinner party to model the different frames to all your family and friends, select one or more, mail them all back with your prescription, and then wait a week or so for you glasses to arrive.

Warby Parker did not invent prescription glasses, online shopping, or the postal service. What they did invent was a new way of buying glasses – they changed the user experience, and that changed everything.

SIDEBAR ON THE HISTORY OF MEMORY FOAM AND NASA

---
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 92)

content:
Casper Sleep is a similar example.[[21]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) Think of how we HAVE traditionally bought mattresses. You go to a store (with or without your significant other), lie down on a dozen different mattresses for a few seconds each, and without remembering how any of them felt, pick one at random. And then after three weeks of back pain, you realize that you did not choose wisely.

Casper changed the user experience by offering a free home trial. You order your mattress online. It comes in a box, and you have some period of time to see how it feels before making up your mind whether to keep the mattress or not. All this was made possible by the invention of memory foam in the 1960s under a NASA contract; and the development forty years later of light-weight gel memory foam, more suitable for mattresses.[[22]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) But it was the ability to stuff the mattress into a box and ship it easily that made all the difference, when combined with the risk-free trial. Again, all Casper did was change the user experience, and that changed everything.

SIDEBAR ON THE TASTEE TAPE TEAM

---
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 93)

content:
Here is another example, a little closer to home. A group of engineering students at Hopkins decided that the burrito eating experience needed improvement. As we all know, burritos tend to fall apart when eating them. Determined to fix that problem, the students developed *Tastee Tape*, “which is edible, safe, and has the tensile strength you can trust to hold together a fat burrito.”[[23]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) Again, the students did not invent the burrito; they changed the user experience by focusing on something that was both important and poorly satisfied.

The list of user experiences that can be explored is endless. Whether big stuff like how we interact with government or physicians, or little stuff, like how we interact with burritos. But it starts by looking around and seeing the world and our lives with new eyes; almost as if we were little kids again and seeing the world for the first time.[[24]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

The key tool for understanding and exploring user needs is process mapping. Very simply, you take any process and lay it out step by step, in whatever detail seems appropriate, all the while rating each step for two things:

1. how important it is to the overall goal, and
2. how well satisfied it is
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 94)

content:
We usually have students rank each step on a five-point scale. The sweet spot for innovation is those steps that are both important and poorly satisfied. Additionally, process maps allow you to visualize which steps might be combined or even eliminated. All of which present opportunities for innovation.

SIDEBAR ON THE HISTORY OF COFFEE

---

As a short in-class exercise, we usually ask students to lay out the steps required to make a cup of coffee, specifically an American-type pour over. The process begins with acquiring beans and goes all the way to disposing of the grinds and washing the cup. We then look at how students ranked the steps and see where the opportunities are. For example, there was a time in America when it was not so easy to get good beans; but now that step is well-satisfied. And so it goes.

PICTURE OF COFFEE POT

---

Another critical step in making a proper pour over that for a long time was poorly satisfied, was how to get the temperature of the water right. The temperature should be off the boil, but as it takes several minutes to actually make the cup of coffee, the water can cool to unacceptable levels. Hence the development of pots with specific temperature controls that allow you to hold the desired temperature for the entire coffee making process.

SIDEBAR ON CLAYTON CHRISTENSEN AND HIS DISCUSSION OF SUSTAINING AND DISRUPTIVE INNOVATIONS

---
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 95)

content:
**Jobs to be done** is an important variation on this theme. As described in much work by Clayton Christensen and his colleagues, a job is “the progress that an individual seeks in a given circumstance;[[25]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) with the result that we “hire” products and services to help us do the job.

Take coffee, for example. I buy a cup of coffee in the morning on the way to work to help clear my head. I then have a cup in the afternoon – it gives me an excuse to get away from my desk and chat with others in the kitchenette. After work, I go out with friends where the coffee is simply an excuse for a social gathering. From a marketing perspective, all we see is that I bought three cups of coffee in the day. Marketers can then analyze the purchases and find all kinds of patterns reflected in the demographics and psychographics of the purchaser. But none of this data explains exactly why I bought any of the three cups of coffee. For each of the three, I had a different “job” to do. The question is whether some other product or service offering would help me to do any of these jobs better. And therein lie opportunities for innovation.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 96)

content:
The same can be said about almost any product or service I might buy. Think about how and why we use televisions, smart phones, exercise equipment, cookbooks, dating apps. The list is endless. It is not so much the product itself that matters, but the jobs we are trying to do, the progress we are seeking in any given circumstance. And anytime a job is not done well enough presents an opportunity. And again, process maps can be very helpful here.[[26]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)

Opportunities, therefore, arise when people are not making sufficient progress in their lives. Once you understand a job deeply, what people are actually trying to accomplish (and according to Christensen we can only discover jobs, not invent them), then you can start to devise innovations (products, services, and policies) that can help them better do this job; or eliminate the things that prevent them from doing the job well. Christensen writes that jobs are not statistics, but stories. They require deep knowledge of what people are doing and trying to do.

Here is a true story from one of the authors:
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 97)

content:
For many years, I would get a call from my 80-year-old mother every day asking me the same question every day, “Why don’t your children ever call me (meaning her grandchildren)
 And every day, I would answer the same, “Because you don’t communicate with them the way that they like to communicate (i.e. texting and email).” I tried twice to get my mother to use a computer. But it was hopeless. She could not figure out right and left clicks and was constantly getting lost in the system. I gave up and suffered with her daily phone calls.

In 2010, the first iPad appeared. And for the life of me, I could not figure out what anybody would do with one. I had a computer and a smartphone and an iPod. I was convinced it was an Apple folly. But it did not disappear into the dumpster of bad products. So one day, I went to the store and got one of the youngsters working there to show me an iPad and how it worked. It slowly dawned on me that this could be the answer. It was intuitive in the sense that you used your finger, not a mouse, and if you got lost, you just hit the home button.

I bought one and took it to my mother. Within a week, she was texting her grandchildren and facetiming with her great-grandchildren every day. She was chatting with women she had gone to nursing school with during World War II and had not seen in decades. She was playing scrabble with strangers all over the world. And had assembled a library of her favorite opera singers from the 1930s.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 98)

content:
There is not a doubt in my mind that my mother is alive today because of that iPad. The job she wanted to do was simple, to connect with people she loved and cared about, and the tools at hand, telephones and computers were inadequate. The iPad changed everything. But the device only mattered because it allowed my mother to make progress in the circumstances that mattered to her.

1.      Choose a domain of interest to you and that you know well.

2.      Identify a job to be done in that domain.

·       In other words, what are people trying to accomplish; what progress are they looking to make, i.e., what specific outcomes are they looking for

3.      What is preventing them from doing the job they want to do

·       Use a process map.

·       Rate the steps in the process according to importance and satisfaction

4.      Where are the opportunities

---

This is the process we typically use in class:

***Challenging Orthodoxies***

Another of Gibson’s Four Lenses is challenging orthodoxies, assumptions, accepted wisdom, and paradigms.

**Challenging Orthodoxies – What’s Next for an Industry Space**

content:

**Chapter Six – Exploring Specific Domains**

Until now, we have spent time building a toolkit. But at this point in the course, rather than focus on practicing with a specific tool, students begin to use whatever tool (or tools) seems appropriate to the space they want to explore. Our goal now is to have them explore the technological and market limits embodied in ill-defined problems specific to particular domains.
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 105)

content:
A good example of this is the idea of a “reverse salient,” first described by Thomas P. Hughes in his famous study of the process of electrification:

SIDEBAR ON THE HISTORY OF ELECTRIFICATION

---

Having explored the nature of the invention, development, and transfer of Edison’s direct current system, we now turn to the endeavor of inventors and engineers to maintain the momentum by solving the critical problems that frustrated growth of the system. “Evolution” is an apt metaphor for an electric supply system like Edison’s because internal forces alone did not direct its growth; the system grew within a context of geographical, economic, political, and organizational factors.

http://www.diva-portal.se/smash/get/diva2:953334/FULLTEXT01.pdf

---
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 106)

content:
… ****The idea of a reverse salient suggests the need for concentrated action (invention and development) if expansion is to proceed. **A reverse salient appears in an expanding system when a component of the system does not march along harmoniously with other components.** As the system evolves toward a goal, some components fall behind or out of line. As a result of the reverse salient, growth of the entire enterprise is hampered, or thwarted, and thus remedial action is required. The reverse salient usually appears as a result of accidents and confluences that persons presiding over or managing the system do not foresee, or, if they do foresee them, are unable to counter expeditiously. The causes of the lag can arise from within the system; from its environment, or context; or from some complex combination thereof. The reverse salient will not be seen, however, unless inventors, engineers, and others view the technology as a goal-seeking system.

… Innumerable (probably most) inventions and technological developments result from efforts to correct reverse salients .[[1]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 107)

content:
In other words, the development of a system, i.e. technological change, is “held up” when one part of the system does not keep pace with advances in other parts of the system, reminding us again of the idea of nested hierarchies. Salients serve as opportunities for innovation and a way of focusing the toolkit developed in these chapters on specific domains and areas of interest.

SIDEBAR WITH OTHER CASE STUDIES – ALEXANDER ROVALINO CAN HELP HERE

---

The exact solution to the problems of electrification is beyond the scope of this book, although the “essence of the concept was a unified system embracing, or coupling, generators (supply) and loads of varying characteristics (demand).”[[2]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) Similar stories can be found in the history of the development of other large technological systems, for example automobiles, airplanes, nuclear power, integrated circuits, air-conditioning, smartphones, where specific “holdups” led to innovative activity. In other words, wherever a limit has been reached, something new is required.

And the same can clearly be said of more “contemporary” technological systems. Here are some examples we use with students:
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 108)

content:
1. Green electrification (energy density)
2. AI (energy consumption)
3. Space travel (weight capacity)
4. Genome sequencing (cost)
5. Chip production (physics, workforce expertise, manufacturing systems)
6. Nuclear fusion (confinement subsystem)
7. Recycling (quality degradation)
8. Water infrastructure (age)
9. Rail infrastructure (track speed, track ownership)
10. Livestock farming (land utilization)

1.      Research a domain.

2.      Prepare a domain map.

3.      Identify the reverse salient.

- Why is this a reverse salient

- What measures of efficiency, effectiveness, reliability, profitability, useability, etc. are not being met

4.      Identify opportunities. Use tools as appropriate. Be clear as to which tools you used.

5.      Think in terms of

- Intersectional innovations
- New scientific and technological trends
- Jobs to be done
- The four actions framework
- Scenarios
- Systems analysis

---

In summary, when asking what is the next big thing in a particular space, the idea of a reverse salient can be very helpful in directing innovative activities, independent of the tools utilized. This is the process we typically use in class:
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 109)

content:
Another way to explore domains using a broad toolkit is to take advantage of product life cycles in their entirety. The idea of a life cycle is obviously biological in origin, and per the Encyclopedia Britannica, it represents the “series of changes that the members of a species undergo as they pass from the beginning of a given developmental stage to the inception of that same developmental stage in a subsequent generation.”[[3]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 110)

content:
Product life cycles are often familiar to students after they have had classes in marketing. But what we have in mind here is less the birth-growth-maturation-death of a specific product, and more the entire production-use-disposal cycle of a product. For those of us who have long been enamored of Pietra Rivoli’s *The Travels of a T-Shirt in the Global Economy*,[[4]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) the idea of a product life cycle from the extraction of raw materials to the final disposal of a product can be thought of as something like a product’s “biography.”[[5]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21) And like most biographies, there are lots of good and happy moments as well as sad ones and plenty of places for regret. It is these latter that provide opportunities for innovation.

Along similar lines, a recent article in the *Washington Post* analyzed “The Steep Price of Blue Jeans:”[[6]](https://www.notion.so/PWS-Innovation-Under-Uncertainty-A-Structured-Approach-19f218d946948085a72aff60d559a969
pvs=21)
title: Pws Innovation Book (Part 111)

content:
Let’s imagine your favorite jeans. They started off in a field of cotton — or more likely hundreds of different fields — probably in India, China, the US, Brazil or Pakistan, the five countries that make up 75% of global cotton production. Once the fibers have been separated from the seeds, in a process known as ginning, they’ll be spun into yarn and subsequently dyed. For denim, that usually means an indigo dye. Once woven and sewn into garments, fashionable faded looks are created through finishing processes such sandblasting, stonewashing and acid-washing. It’s a long and complicated supply chain spanning multiple countries and businesses.

SIDEBAR ON HISTORY BLUE JEANS AND LEVI STRAUSS

content:
**Every step comes with a significant environmental effect**. According to Levi Strauss & Co., a pair of 501 jeans, the company’s signature cut, used nearly 3,000 liters of water by the time it hit the shop floor and emitted 20 kilograms of CO2e (a measure that encompasses all greenhouse gases) in 2015. Prolific use of pesticides and fertilizers are bad for both nature and human workers. Indigo dye used to be natural, made from the leaves of the *indigofera tinctoria* plant, or true indigo. Now, however, the vast majority of dye is synthetic and contains toxic pollutants, including formaldehyde and cyanide. In some parts of the world, waste from the dye process is dumped straight into waterways, tinting rivers the colors of the forthcoming fashion season. Finishing processes can be equally polluting, resource-intensive and dangerous for workers who, too often, aren’t given the right protective equipment.

**…if we’re going to make truly planet-friendly jeans, companies will have to immerse themselves in every part of their products’ life cycles**, break down those silos and swallow some higher costs.

      1. This is not a problem in the normal sense of the word

title: I&E Lecture Notes Fall.Docx (Part 13)

content:
1. READ FROM SLIDE
      2. Uncertainty is not risk
      3. Risk is the probability of loss, injury, or other adverse outcome. It can be estimated and calculated based on our knowledge of prior outcomes and conditions. It has been mathematically formulated since the late 17th century, notably in the work of Blaise Pascal. Most importantly, it can be managed. Risk can be distributed (syndicated), insured against, hedged, and reduced. In short, it can be quantified and controlled.
      4. Uncertainty is different. It is not subject to exact quantification. It was only recently formalized in the early 20th century work of the economist Frank Knight. It represents all of the possible future states of the world at any given time. The higher the uncertainty, the greater the number of possible outcomes, both positive and negative. It is a source of discomfort because we cannot predict it, but it is also a source of potential value. Higher uncertainty means greater potential, and most of us underestimate the extent of that potential since there are more possible future states of the world than we can possibly comprehend.
      5. While some view the two as essentially the same and use the words interchangeably, uncertainty is quite distinct from risk, both in its character and in its use. In fact, what sets highly successful entrepreneurs and innovators apart from the rest of the population is the ability to see and use this difference as the basis for their success. The good news is that we can learn from them.
      6. Btw, this distinction is also why most companies want to size existing markets -- if you have heard the expression "TAM" or "SAM" (total addressable market, or serviceable addressable market), these are measures of existing, known, markets, since one can numerically estimate the current size of these. My corporate clients often ask me to help them estimate these sizes.    
      7. Entrepreneurs on the other hand discover entirely new markets -- there is no "addressable market" until they do what Drucker famously said in Innovation and Entrepreneurship, which is, to "create a customer."  Once we know there are customers for, say, hula hoops or carbonated drinks or spreadsheets, only then can we create an estimate of a TAM.
      8. We manage risk, but exploit uncertainty
      9. Entrepreneurs and innovators see value in uncertainty since they earn profits when gains are appreciably greater than is generally expected.

METHOD 2: SCENARIO ANALYSIS
1. How to Use Scenario Analysis
   1. Scenario analysis is a second technique we use to think differently about the future
      1. Again, this is the entire point of un-defined problems
   2. The key idea here (and really of both techniques) is that we are not predicting what the future will be, but describing alternative possible futures that are rooted in what is actually happening now
   3. Trend analysis is straightforward – take a trend, carry it forward, and see if anything interesting shows up
   4. Scenario analysis is different – it is more formal
      1. It posits a set of possible futures, but attaches no probabilities
      2. It creates stories along known dimensions 
   5. READ THE SLIDE – this is the way we create scenarios
2. Not the Nine Box Matrix
   1. Scenario analysis is not some version of the 9-box matrix, a popular HR tool used to measure employee performance and to identify employees with leadership potential, created by McKinsey in 1970
      1. It was later adapted by GE to identify key investments and to compare various business units
      2. The problem is that probability and impact can really only be measured for low uncertainty opportunities
   2. By contrast, scenario analysis is not a predictive tool, but a descriptive tool by which we create alternative futures that can then be explored for problems and opportunities
3. Example: The Future of Education
   1. Let’s take an example
   2. What is the future of education
   3. How would you even begin answering that
      1. One way is a trend analysis – what will the world look like if we never return to traditional classrooms
      2. Or, what will the world look like if we are all taught by robots
   4. With scenario analysis, we build four possible, but distinct futures, and then ask what we might find, or not find, there
   5. The key starting step is choice of axes – you can see several possibilities on the slide
      1. A good place to get axes is from a trend analysis
      2. The point is that there is no perfect way to do scenarios – the only good answer is one that you find useful
   6. Very important – the scenarios need to mirror each other
4. Scenario Analysis for Education
   1. These are the two axes that we chose – delivery method (virtual or in-person) and method of instruction (a real teacher or a robot with AI)
   2. You will notice that scenarios are given descriptive names, usually accompanied by pictures
5. Descriptions of the Scenarios
   1. The next step is to actually write the descriptions
   2. In general, this would require real research and an analysis of current trends
   3. Extremely important – the scenarios need to mirror each other, i.e. the same kind of stuff needs to be in each box
6. Opportunities from Scenario Analysis
   1. The last step is to then search each scenario for the interesting problems that might be found in such a future – take a look at the ones on the slide
   2. Problems are, of course, opportunities; and the key is to find the most interesting opportunities that could actually be started today
   3. A simple way of thinking about this is to ask what kinds of products and services and policies will be needed if this future comes to pass

title: I&E Lecture Notes Fall.Docx (Part 32)

content:
1. Systems give us another way to think about un-defined problems and escape from presentism
   2. So what is a system
 – an interconnected set of elements that is coherently organized in a way that achieves something. 
      1. Systems are not random collections of elements.
   3. A system must consist of three kinds of things: 
      1. elements, 
      2. interconnections, and 
      3. a function or purpose.
   4. Elements, interconnections, and functions can be placed into what we call a nested hierarchy

ILL-DEFINED PROBLEMS
1. Problem Types
   1. Innovation begins with finding problems worth solving
   2. Our point is that there are different kinds of problems with different time horizons, different degrees of uncertainty and risk, and they cannot be addressed or “solved” in all the same way
      1. Un-defined problems are addressed by exploring possible futures and seeing what kinds of problems might be found there that can be addressed starting today
   3. Ill-defined problems are still traditional in the sense that they are present forward; by contrast, un-defined problems are future backward
2. Ill-Defined Problems
   1. Ill-defined problems look at what is plausible in a technology or market space or customer experience in order to find the next big problem worth working on
      1. The point is that many, many things could answer the question, “What’s the next big thing
”
   2. And like un-defined problems, ill-defined problems help us create a portfolio of innovation
3. Example: What’s Next Big Thing for Electric Vehicles
   1. Ill-defined problems are not about imagining distant futures, but operate on a shorter time horizon and ask “What’s the next big thing here, in this specific space
”
   2. For example, the question on this slide is not “What’s the future of electric vehicles
” but what’s the next big thing for anyone who will use or manufacture them
4. Example: Baltimore Harbor
1. Here is an example
2. It all began when students went down to the Baltimore Harbor and were shocked by the amount of pollution they saw there; and decided they wanted to do something 
3. Let’s be clear – they did not ask about future state of the harbor
   1. Rather, the question they asked themselves was how to clean up pollution in waterways
   2. The possibilities are near endless
5. Framing an Ill-Defined Problem
1. Which is what makes it an ill-defined problem – there is no single solution for the simple reason that there is no clearly defined problem yet that can be solved
1. Something is missing; something is needed to constrain the problem
2. Supplying those constraints is what then allows us to begin building the lists that are the “answer” to an ill-defined problem
2. It is the ability to drive the creation of such lists that represents the true power of ill-defined problems (as well as un-defined problems)
1. And from that list you pick the ones you want to work on
6. The Process for Creating an Ill-Defined Problem
   1. So the first thing the students did to address this ill-defined space was to supply the missing elements by clarifying what kind of waterway, and what kind of pollution
   2. They decided to focus on trash in inland waterways
   3. And then they made lists of opportunities using a set of tools and techniques
   4. And the lists were quite extensive – similar to the DTA example on the first day
7. The Solution
   1. Then they picked one opportunity and turned it into a well-defined problem
   2. In this case – how to continuously clean up trash from inland waterways with minimal human intervention and oversight
 – what you see here
   3. They designed and built a robot that uses AI and computer vision to clean up the harbor – something like a water-based Roomba
      1. This is a well-defined problem because whatever solution they built either worked or it did not – the solution was falsifiable
8. The PixieDrone
1. And, of course, they were years ahead of their time – there are now lots of companies out there chasing the students’ idea, for example the one you see here
2. Over the years, our students have probably left hundreds of millions of dollars worth of funding on the table from all the good ideas they have chosen not to pursue
9. Summary: Using Ill-Defined Problems
   1. To summarize, ill-defined problems are very different from un-defined problems
      1. They do not ask about future states in a very uncertain world, but simply what is plausibly the next big thing inherent in this particular situation
      2. And the key is that there is no single answer; in fact, many things could actually address the “problem”
      3. Hence, we make lists
   2. Like un-defined problems, ill-defined problems can help us create a bank of interesting opportunities
      1. From which we can then select the best ones and turn them into well-defined problems that can actually be solved
10. Tools for Exploring Ill-Defined Problems
   1. So how do we actually explore ill-defined problems – through a combination of intensive and extensive searching of market and technological spaces

1. Ill-Defined Problems

2. The Problem of Electrification
   1. What we are going to do in this section is take a look at how the toolkit can be expanded and applied to specific domains, starting with what are know as reverse salient
   2. The term comes from the famous book by Thomas Hughes on the history of electrification in the industrialized world, and specifically the US
   3. Electricity only begins in the 1880s, specifically to light streets, houses, and buildings
   4. The power plants are small and the distribution is limited
   5. The question that he sets out to answer is how these small, local systems morphed into regional inter-connected systems
   6. And the emphasis is on the words system and network, hence the title of his book, Networks of Power
3. How do you Electrify Everything
title: I&E Lecture Notes Fall.Docx (Part 65)

content:
1. This is a picture of electricity generation in Pennsylvania in 1900
